comment:
good for going south (A1) or east. 
Bus 91/92, get out at "Kurt-Schumacher-Damm"

name: Anonymous
comment:
Going North (A1). Better make a sign. 
Buses 41 and 81/82

name: Anonymous
comment: on A7, A5, and A4. at the intersection by burger king is good for any direction.  people stop for food and gas, and will pick you up.

name: Anonymous
comment: This is a restplace, an extremely good hitching spot. If someone offers you a ride to the nearest gas station, think twice, because this is almost too good a spot to lose!

name: Anonymous
comment: Be sure to be ready for when the ferry arrives: a big rush of cars comes by, but then nothing for the coming half hour until the next ferry arrives. Good place to stop a car;

name: Anonymous
comment: We got a ride within 10 min. good place to stop too. friendly people

name: Anonymous
comment: No fucking way out of this shithole... bad place to stop, little traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment: "grÃ¼nes Herz" its the best place to go from Kiel to Berlin on the motorway A21

name: Anonymous
comment:
DIRECTION: NORTH, Rostock

I was standing there for no more than 20 minutes, got a ride straight to Rostock. I had a label saying 'Rostock'. Maybe it was just luck, but the 104 road goes exactly this direction. You can stand behind the crossroads or ask people at the Oil! petrol station 150 m west. 150 m east there is truck park also.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to hitch towards Freiburg for people who don't want to wait for the bus or hitchhikers who have been dropped out at gas station "schauinsland". You can let them drop you out at moosweiher to take the tram no. 1 towards inner city.

name: Anonymous
comment: Gasstation on the border to Germany/Belgium

name: Anonymous
comment: I didnt wait longer than 15 minutes to get a very friendly ride there :) - Flov

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot for hitchhiking north towards Berlin. Opinions differ about this ramp, but usually it's possible. Try to wait on the traffic islands.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot, hitchhiking possible in both directions. Most traffic goes southwards! Easy to stop for cars along the hard shoulder.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to stand along the ramp, but nearly no traffic going this way!

name: Anonymous
comment: Just behind the roundabout, cars are slow, good spot for hitchhiking towards IbbenbÃ¼ren, Uffeln, Steinbeck, Dickenberg, PÃ¼sselbÃ¼ren.

name: Anonymous
comment: There is a big bus stop where cars can stop. But sometimes the cars are a bit fast there.  IN the evening you can try to get a lift at the traffic lights at the crossways WÃ¼rmtalstraÃŸe/FÃ¼rstenrieder StraÃŸe

name: Anonymous
comment:
Dir. East

Falkensteig is the first possibility to hitch a ride along the B31 coming from Freiburg. There is enough space for cars to stop, they have to go slow (there is a traffic light somewhere) and there is plenty of traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Dir: Feldberg

Coming from Freiburg, you can either choose to take the official B317, or this "secret" road passing "Bruderhalde". There is not that much traffic, but it's much easier for cars to stop and somebody will eventually pick you up.

name: Anonymous
comment: This Bridge was reconstructed in spring 2008, there is no possibility to stop for cars anymore!!!

name: Anonymous
comment: End of town, enough space to stop cars. Many Dutch cars along this way.

name: Anonymous
comment: Traffic island to stand on for hitchhiking.Cars have to stop along the street, but that might be possible. Most traffic goes towards Nordhorn, but if cars go up the highway they mostly go to the NL. Many Dutch cars here. Spot is doable, but expect some waiting time. Forget it on Sundays!

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good for direction Prenzlau, Szeczin.
Take a tram to Indira-Gandhi-Str. Then walk or take a bus along the Berliner Allee and find a decent place where cars can pull over.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Very great place. You can easily get very long lifts in any direction.
From Bruchsal train station, take bus no. 125 to "Rasthof Ost" for north or "Rasthof West" for south.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good hitchhiking spot for hitching direction A2. Parking with enough space to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: Hitchhiking spot some 50m behind the traffic light. Take the tram to Sieker and hitch some rides/walk along the Detmolder Strasse until this traffic lights. Here the approach road to the highway begins. Excellent spot.

name: Anonymous
comment: Probably your best chance is asking the Danes, shopping at the hypermarket before crossing the border. To get there, take the bus towards Niebuell and get off after the bus underpasses the highway.

name: Anonymous
comment: At the end of the village of Birgte this is the best spot for hitching towards Saerbeck, Emsdetten, Greven and MÃ¼nster. The road is only leading towards Saerbeck, and you'll have enough space here for stopping cars.

name: Anonymous
comment: Here you find a gas station and traffic lights. Just before the lights is some space to stand on and stopping cars. Another option is to ask people at the pump.Might be easy to get rides towards Bielefeld and Versmold, but difficult to get rides toward the highway, very small ramp, fast traffic, much trucks.

name: Anonymous
comment: where the "middle ring road" is coming out of the tunnel there is enough place to stop for cars and they don't go too fast. good place, although watch out for ants!

name: Anonymous
comment: Resting place - direction Prague. Not many cars passing, but many going to prague, if you ask the drivers, you get away in cca. half an hour. (i was lucky that driver originally going berlin -chemnitz took me there).

name: Anonymous
comment: it is only a small petrol station but just 5km west of the border to austria. its the last chance to get the vignette here before austria (people need a vignette to travel on austrian highways) and so it makes it very good spot to find a lift in direction east (Linz, Wien) a bit harder is it to find someone to the south (Villach, Italy, Slovenia) but it is also a doable thing here

name: Anonymous
comment: on a friday morning (even on a day when holidays in bavaria were started) it took me over 2 hours to get away with my "salzburg" sign and also only to munich city. there is only low traffic on this station

name: Anonymous
comment: many cars are going the b9 in direction remagen, andernach, koblenz. place yourself somewhere, whre a car is able to stop and it will only take some minutes to get away.  dont await very long lifts

name: Anonymous
comment: deutsch: nach richtung penzberg trampen --- enlish:hitchhiking direction to penzberg

name: Anonymous
comment: nach mÃ¼nchen rein geht super, auf der auffahrt aber vor dem autobahnschild stehen! --- good place to munich, stand on driveway but in front of highway-sign!

name: Anonymous
comment: deutsch: penzberg richtung iffeldorf/ seeshaupt/ autobahn --- english: penzberg direction iffeldorf/ seeshaupt/ highway

name: Anonymous
comment: needed over 1.5 hours to get a ride in direction dortmund. most people are heading direct to the north to duisburg or something. must be better weekdays but dont know. to the south or the north this is doable but it is difficult to the northeast...

name: Anonymous
comment: this service station seems to be highly frequented by other hitchhikers. there is a huge sation on the side which leeds to the west and you will be able to find a lift in direction dortmund within a few minutes to the west, this is almost excellent). a bit more difficult is to find someone who changes to motorway to the a7 to the north. and even more difficult to find someone heading to the south from here. there is a small service area on the other side on the motorway which enables you to find a lift in direction east (berlin) too

name: Anonymous
comment: this ramp is an agreeable position to leave braunschweig in direction west

name: Anonymous
comment: this is only a better parking on the a2 but there is enough traffic to get away... be a bit patient

name: Anonymous
comment: this is a good spot for hitchhiking in both directions on the a7.

name: Anonymous
comment: seems to be excellent to get a lift to hamburg but it is a bit more difficult to get a lift farer than hamburg on the a7 but at least a good point in both directions

name: Anonymous
comment: I waited 20 minutes here to go to Dusseldorf, but the guy took me to another place.. can't judge based on one time !

name: Anonymous
comment: Towards MÃ¼nster, worked great ! Got to have a clear ad, considering the numerous possibilities !

name: Anonymous
comment: to go to kiel this seems to be a possible spot from hamburg. many cars are entering the a7 to the north from here

name: Anonymous
comment:
Gas station on the motorway "Wetterau". There is a tunnel so you can easyly cross the motorway.
Excellent stop if you're going north either to Dortmund or Kassel. 
Comming from Dortmund I stop here, switch sides and go up north and east to chemnitz very often. Faster than directly trying to get east.
Very very many cars go north from here!!!!

name: Anonymous
comment: many traffic but no place where cars can stop. the only way is to ask at the traffic light...

name: Anonymous
comment: gas station at the motorway that you can easily reach by bus from lÃ¼denscheid center. Use the bus to Kalve where you can get on the stations on either way over the supply ramps. Usualy you'll find somebody, but the stations are not too crowded.

name: Anonymous
comment: to go to the south on the a7. from braunschweig take the bus to rÃ¼ningen and exit at station raabestraÃŸe. then cross the bridge and walk about 300m over the fields to the station. not many traffic at this station but almost better as if you would wait on the highway entry

name: Anonymous
comment: to the north or to the northwest, this seems to be a good position. find someone to change to the A3 if you want to go to Frankfurt or GieÃŸen. Or find someone to follow the A7 in direction Fulda, Kassel.

name: Anonymous
comment: Gas station "Irxleben", good to get lifts Southeast to Halle/Saale, Leipzig or East to Berlin or Magdeburg

name: Anonymous
comment: when heading to ulm or stuttgart, this is a good spot.

name: Anonymous
comment: small petrol station to get west on the A8.

name: Anonymous
comment: Service station "Helmstedt Süd",next station in 5km!(old border East Germany), good to get lifts to Mageburg, Berlin or Poland!

name: Anonymous
comment:
DÃ¼sseldorf,SÃ¼dring 115
Aral gas station.
Direction  Aachen, Belgium A46.
Tram 712 to SÃ¼dring

name: Anonymous
comment: Traffic lights and bus stop. Easy to get rides to the city center. Your spot if you got off at the service station for going towards Muenster

name: Anonymous
comment: here is a bus-stop and a petrol station. this spot is excellent to get to braunschweig or to the a2. never waited longer than 10 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot for hitching out of Weingarten towards direction Ulm. Make sure you have a sign. Cars can stop along the road.

name: Anonymous
comment: Great place, for east (A6), north or south (A5). Take the tram no. 1, 2, S4 or S5 to Weinweg. It's a double-ramp, on the south side there is more traffic and more place to pull over.

name: Anonymous
comment: Gas station, good to get lifts in direction Ravensburg

name: Anonymous
comment: small petrol station at the A1. no problem to get away, but not very comfortable here.

name: Anonymous
comment: This Autohof is a bad place to get away: mostly regional cars. But maybe you're lucky asking the truckers.

name: Anonymous
comment:
After the red lights.
People is stoping there, so they have time to see you

name: Anonymous
comment:
Gas station Breisgau

Excellent place to hitch north from Freiburg. Get here by taking bus no. 33 or 35 to Tiengen Bus stop Im MaierbrÃ¼hl. Major traffic here, you won't have to wait long to find the right car. It's even worth taking the bus from freiburg which takes one hour alltogether. It's good to print out the way from the bus stop to the gas station though, or you'll end up with very dirty shoes.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Dir. East

Just a couple of meter before the tunnel there is enough space to stop infront of Sport Kiefer. 10-20 minutes to get a ride.

name: Anonymous
comment:
good place to hh
direction of Liege, Namur, Bruxeles. Hh  times and stops only womens :)

name: Anonymous
comment: Emergency rest stop before the traffic light. Very good if you are going towards Metelen. If going north, just cross the street and try it along the hard shoulder. This spot was recommended to me by the German border police ;) It's also easy to get rides here towards Enschede.

name: Anonymous
comment: A great place, but a lot of local traffic. You should at least get a lift to the service area 'Lichtendorf' easily.

name: Anonymous
comment: great spot for hitching west (Chemnitz, Leipzig Erfurt, Jena)... just show a sign saying C,L, EF, J, etc...

name: Anonymous
comment: Walk from Hörstel City to Rheine-Kanalhafen (Bus only 2x per day), there you can try to get up on the A30 direction Amsterdam.Never try it on a sunday,wasteful! within a week lot of people to Rheine or further, nice to get a lift to the ramp Rheine-Nord which is ways better!

name: Anonymous
comment: A crossing with a bay, maybe good for hitching towards Oldenzaal (NL). It's just 300m south of the train station.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Somewhere around here must be a petrol station where you can ask for cars leaving Stuttgart. I have no experiences if that works well.

To get here you can take the S-Bahn to SchwabstraÃŸe and walk up the RotebÃ¼hlstraÃŸe or take the bus.

name: Anonymous
comment: Ugly environment and car drivers who don't like to stop for hitchikers. I've been told that whole Mühlacker is inhabited with people like that.

name: Anonymous
comment:
When the boss of the gas station is trying to chase you away (happens sometimes), you can try to stand here with a sign. 

The drak street is probably not owned by the gas station and the boss should have no right to make you go away.

name: Anonymous
comment: At this place infront of Mc Shit people drop of their friends for the trainstation. ask them to give you a ride onto the highway

name: Anonymous
comment: Ask people standing in Line for the traffic light to turn left. You'll find somebody to bring you to the highway-gasstations.

name: Anonymous
comment: Hitchhikers hell. I was dropped of here at night, no traffic at all, pitch dark, had to walk 30 minutes to the tram-station in rieselfeld.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Dir: South (Basel) only!!!

Gasstation Schauinsland

OK traffic

You can get here from Freiburg by taking Bus No. 36 towards Hochdorf, exit Bus station HÃ¶gestraÃŸe. Makes sense if you're trying to make a long distance. Otherwise you might just stay at KronenbrÃ¼cke, all together it will take the same amount of time.

Coming from the north it works the same, if you want to get to freiburg let them drop you out here, try to find someone who is going directly to freiburg or take bus no. 36.

name: Anonymous
comment: Gasstation: Direction Aachen, Belgium, Paris.

name: Anonymous
comment: The perfect place to go to Hamburg and Kiel. For Berlin itÂ´s the best way to go from here via Hamburg as well and change at the circle Horner Kreisel.

name: Anonymous
comment:
For Berlin itÂ´s much better to start from Fackenburger Allee/LohmÃ¼hle and go via Hamburg!
In St. Hubertus wait up to 2 hours.

name: Anonymous
comment: there was much traffic on the road on tuesday evening but really nobody was willing to give me a lift

name: Anonymous
comment: this pertrol station and restaurant is like all the bigger stations on the a7 really good to get away

name: Anonymous
comment: Service Station Brockenlande, much traffic towards Kiel, a bit less up to Denmark. But possible to get rides up to the border.

name: Anonymous
comment: not many traffic, must be a bit lucky. you can also ask the drivers at the petrol station and macdonalds on the other side of the road.

name: Anonymous
comment: Service station just before the gates of Hamburg, but a bit a dead spot. Waited quite long there and only got ride offers for Hamburg City. Hard to get a ride somewhere north of HH.

name: Anonymous
comment: Service station close to a Burger King. It is not directly on the expressway (germ. Autobahn A9) but very close to it. Advantage: You can take a bus from the city centre or take a walk to the service station.

name: Anonymous
comment: If you have to change your driver because you want to hitchhike the A8 to Munich - (and your driver wants to Stuttgart-city or s.l.t.)this is a good place to change

name: Anonymous
comment: Traffic is to fast to stop. most cars will not go to the highway but go straight ahead. i hh here twice. Once i get a lift after 40min. next time i waited over 100min and finally gave up!

name: Anonymous
comment:
If you want to hitchhike from Nuremberg to Munich or elsewhere south and you donÂ´t know nobody with a car -  this is my hotspot. Just take the S-Bahn Nr. 3 to Feucht and then you can walk to this servicestation - directly on the motorway (germ. Autobahn)Just follow the Schwarzenbrucker StraÃŸe and turn left (uphill) after the first bridge but befor the next railroad bridge. 

For me there is just one disatvantage if you are in a hurry - from the S-Bahn station Feucht to the servicestation youÂ´ll need around 45 min.

name: Anonymous
comment: If you wanna go North/South or you have to change your driver "KÃ¶schinger Forst" is an excellent place. It is situated about 10 km south from the motorway exit "Ingolstadt Nord"

name: Anonymous
comment: Big bus bay with lots of space to stop for cars. They can see you easily and have to slow down to 70 km/h some meters before. Good for direction Dreierwalde, Hoerstel or Hopsten.

name: Anonymous
comment: really very good to go into cologne city. enough traffic for more directions

name: Anonymous
comment: no problem to get a lift to the south in direction kassel

name: Anonymous
comment: 10 min walk from the citycentre for the east and west germany

name: Anonymous
comment: Good if wanting to go to Marburg. It's not a practicle place for cars to pull over, but many just stop directly on the road since there is not too much traffic. waiting time: 15 - 30 min.

name: Anonymous
comment: Perfect for going toward Hamburg, Dresden, or Berlin. If you are in Giessen, which is hard to get out of, try taking a bus to Reiskirchen, get out first stop, and track back the direction you came from until you get to the Autobahn ramp.

name: Anonymous
comment: Few traffic going up here, you might wait some time until cars going up on the highway. But nevertheless a nice countryside. Unprotected spot, can be very breezy.

name: Anonymous
comment: Service station Münsterland, much traffic on the way towards Dortmund (Ruhrarea), Cologne, Hamburg etc. Also chance to get on the A43 to Recklinghausen and Gelsenkirchen.

name: Anonymous
comment: A small petrol station in the western ring of the A10. Not so much traffic but at least no Problem if you get to the west or to the south. I waited 17 min for a lift to Hannover.

name: Anonymous
comment: to Freyung, to Czeh republic (Praha). Just say before traficlight with writen destination place on your hhiker's plate. A lot of local cars, but people are friendly and will take you very fast from this point.

name: Anonymous
comment: much traffic! slow cars. no problem to get away to france, luxembourg or germany. there is a turkish restaurant with a parking in direction north and a small snack stand with place for cars to stop on the other direction of the road. i wated about 5 min.

name: Anonymous
comment:
my personally best hitch hicking point of the world to Hamburg.
you can ask the people their for a lift to hamburg at the petrol station.

name: Anonymous
comment: very nice spot, for going to Hamburg(or to parts in NRW), but you really need a sign their.

name: Anonymous
comment: The Autohof here is the worst place ever to get out of. Located off the Autobahn, lots of local traffic or traffic just going into Stuttgart

name: Anonymous
comment:
Direction: East

Many cars only come for fueling to this gas station and then go back to Salzwedel. It should be easy to find somebody to bring you there but I don't know how many of them can bring you to the other side of the city to go on hitchhiking.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Direction: West. 

This gas station is mostly frequented by people coming from Salzwedel going to... Salzwedel. But there are also some going the direction of Uelzen and maybe after one hour or longer there will be somebody taking you there. 

I recommend asking people while fueling and standing next to the road the rest of the time.

name: Anonymous
comment: Nearly no traffic, you need to have luck to hitch here. Well space for cars to stop, but not for trucks. Better try the ramp or go back. Empty area!

name: Anonymous
comment: Nearly no traffic along this road, and even less going onto the highway towards the NL. Forget it!

name: Anonymous
comment: This spot is somewhat better, more traffic going eastwards to Rheine or IbbenbÃ¼ren. Hitched this direction 2 times, both waiting time around 5 minutes

name: Anonymous
comment: End of town, stupid corner behind you so make yourself visible. Much traffic towards Bentheim, but a bit difficult for cars to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: Just behind the traffic light you can stand for hitching towards Oldenzaal or Gildehaus. Not much traffic, but cars can stop along the road. Average spot.

name: Anonymous
comment: From Bochum central station, take the U35 towards Rensingstrasse. Get out there and walk up to the ramp.

name: Anonymous
comment: Decent Rasthof to continue further to the west (Belgium - Aachen - NL), You can even access it from Cologne by taking a train to Konigsdorf and walk from the station to the Services (Augustinus Str and Marienhofer Weg)

name: Anonymous
comment: no car can stop here...its a bypass road and there is almost no space for you to place yourself. also the cars are coming with over 100km/h and the road is curved...so they cannot see you. better go to fÃ¼rstenwalde west and try your luck there!

name: Anonymous
comment: The traffic is too local and too sparse to make of this spot a logic start out of Cologne

name: Anonymous
comment: For A1 East (Hamburg). Just outside the McDonalds. The road is quite fast but there is a huge space on the side to stop and people see you from some distance.

name: Anonymous
comment: Service station on German side.You can get lifts up north to Karlsruhe or further. Much trucks from South stop here to sleep overnight to go further north.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Very nice spot general direction south. It's a bit more difficult for straight direction west if you want to enter the Netherlands from the far north to Groningen.
Reasons: IKEA is just behind the spot and hence there are many people from all over the place to buy some furniture. This can also cause problems, when they are totally loaded.
How to get there:
Take either tram line no. 4 or 5 to station 'Huckelriede' then switch over into bus line no. 53 until the end (IKEA) or station 'Carl-Zeiss-Str.'
(one earlier). Be aware that you leave the city boarders, when using Bus 53. You'll need an area-extension if you don't want to dodge the fare.
Good ride and quick hitch,
polarfox (www.BeWelcome.org)

name: Anonymous
comment: Tecklenburger Land Ost: Motorway fillingstation / restaurant. Access on foot via DunkbachstraÃŸe, 49545 Tecklenburg. Direction OsnabrÃ¼ck

name: Anonymous
comment: Tecklenburger Land West: Motorway fillingstation / restaurant. Access on foot via GrafenstraÃŸe, 49545 Tecklenburg. Direction Dortmund

name: Anonymous
comment: There's a Aral-Petrol Station. Ask the drivers. The second one I asked gave me a lift to Kiel. Found the spot on hitchbase.com

name: Anonymous
comment: few traffic, many cars which go in direction southwest (GÃ¶ttingen, Kassel)

name: Anonymous
comment: much traffic at friday afternoon, it tooks me only 5mintes waiting time here to get a lift to Frankfurt

name: Anonymous
comment: Very great place, when you want to go onto the motorway in any direction. Almost any car leaving the city will pass by.

name: Anonymous
comment: Parking area Bentheimer Wald with restaurant, police, many trucks. May be good to get Polish trucks. Not many private cars stopping here. Perfect spot when police is closing the border for controls ;-)

name: Anonymous
comment: RaststÃ¤tte Oberlausitz. Perfect for going to either Poland or Dresden

name: Anonymous
comment: Traffic island to stand on if you want to hitch at this ramp towards Rheine, OsnabrÃ¼ck, A31. Cars can stop some meters behind you, but might be dangerous with quite a lot of traffic. Nevertheless a good spot, waiting time around 10 minutes

name: Anonymous
comment: Nice spot for going north towards Bremen, Hamburg. Enough space at hard shoulder for cars to stop, with traffic lights in front of you.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Very dangerous for cars to stop, but a lot of traffic in Direction DÃ¼sseldorf (A57) or Wuppertal (A1).

You can take a tram to Nussbaumer Str.

name: Anonymous
comment: some oil stations here, but I asked for maybe an hour because many cars stay in cologne or drive only to bonn and there is no oil station up to bonn. But it's possible to go on the A3 to Frankfurt from here.

name: Anonymous
comment:
I waited only a few minutes, there was much traffic. Only problem: There is a fence around the station, so maybe you have to climb. But thatâ€™s no big deal.
To come here take the train â€œRB 25â€ from the cologne main station in the direction â€œMarienheideâ€ or â€œOverathâ€ for 3,20 â‚¬. Leave at â€œStÃ¼mpenâ€ and turn right and go up to the â€œKiefernwegâ€ and turn right. Follow the street that is later called â€œDammelsfurther Wegâ€ up to the â€œPestalozziwegâ€ for maybe 500 meters and turn right. Now you pass the Autobahn and turn right again in the â€œPlantageâ€. Follow this way a few hundred meters through the forest and you will see a service station on the right side. Maybe you have to climb a fence. Now you are on the a station without oil station but much traffic. Easy to get a ride here. Totally it takes approximately 40 minutes from the cologne main station. In my experience this is the best possibility to leave cologne.

name: Anonymous
comment: You can go to "FÃ¼rholzen" by bus and than walk out of the town to the north in direction "Hetzenhausen". After you left the town you will soon see the oil station on the left side. Perfect Place!

name: Anonymous
comment: Take a train to Oberhausen-Sterkrade and then the bus #979 to "Heinrich-Heine-Str." in Bottrop. From there you'll see the highway, just walk towards it. Good spot to hitch away fast towards Hamburg, MÃ¼nster,Hannover, Berlin

name: Anonymous
comment: Ramp towards Rheine and the Netherlands. Quite good hard shoulder, cars from both directions, gas station and Burger King on the other side of the roundabout. So mostly a lot of traffic. You can get here with bus S50 and R63, just get out at "BrÃ¼gge/Disco".

name: Anonymous
comment: Ramp "Lotte", not much traffic and also not the best place for cars to stop. Most will only to towards Laggenbeck or IbbenbÃ¼ren. Prepare yourself for a long waiting time :)

name: Anonymous
comment: RaststÃ¤tte ..Auerswalder Blick.. is a perfect spot asking for rides westbound (A4/A72). Hitching east (Dresden, Berlin) is an easy thing as well

name: Anonymous
comment: bus 81 stop Hellerberge - good heading for Berlin or GÃ¶rlitz

name: Anonymous
comment: two gas stations. If heading east, ask drivers for taking you to RaststÃ¤tte Auerswalder Blick

name: Anonymous
comment: on ramp of the A3 to frankfurt. cars can stop easily here. average waiting (male) time: 1hour or less. if you get a ride just to rasthof siegburg, take it.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Hamburg or Easternsea

name: Anonymous
comment: To Hamburg

name: Anonymous
comment: about 60 minutes to get a lift in direction berlin, to hannover seems to be more effective

name: Anonymous
comment: good traffic, but difficult to find someone in the wanted direction

name: Anonymous
comment:
For heading East (Neustadt, Donaueschingen)

Get to the south east of the city where the Leo-Wohleb-StraÃŸe and SchwarzwaldstraÃŸe meet each other (B31). Somewhere there is a strip of grass right in front of a side road. As this is a busy road leading out of the town waiting time is not very long.

name: Anonymous
comment: It is easy to get a ride from people leaving Bremen airport.

name: Anonymous
comment: Few cars stop here, but they all go into Germany. In that way it is easy to get a lift. Main direction is, Leer, Oldenburg, Bremen, Hannover.

name: Anonymous
comment: stopping a car is no problem here to get to the direction polish border or berlin. most but probable you will only get short lifts on the b1.

name: Anonymous
comment: Great place for going north or south. From the town center, take the tram no. 6 direction Messe/Ost to Kronsberg. Turn left into WÃ¼lferoder StraÃŸe. When the road turns slightly right, follow the small road straight on. 30 minutes walking.

name: Anonymous
comment: Lots of space along the hard shoulder to stop cars. Traffic only coming from OsnabrÃ¼ck-City

name: Anonymous
comment: No real space to stop cars, busy traffic light but hard to stop cars there. Better get to OS-Nahne, most traffic into the city.

name: Anonymous
comment: Car dealer with place for hitchhiker's to stop cars. Take bus 21 from center to get here. (get out at OS-Nahne). Good for both directions along A30.

name: Anonymous
comment:
One possibility to find a lift to the A14 (direction Leipzig) is this traffic light. You may also try to ask people at the ESSO petrol station at the crossing.

Unfortunately the most cars are going to Bernburg only and  the petrol station Plötzetal is behind that.

To go here I took Bus 57 to Flughafen.

name: Anonymous
comment: Theres a bus stop-good for cars to stop. When heading north you can also take people driving south to drop you at the next service station (Rasthof Kassel,less than 5 minutes,has a bridge to get to the other side to head north again). Anyway it is a good idea to have a "rasthof KS" sign,so you might have a chance to catch a local lift you to the service station!

name: Anonymous
comment: Very poor chances to find somebody who is going farther than Leizig on the A14. My advice if you start from Dresden: Try to find somebody on the MeiÃŸner LandstraÃŸe or maybe HansastraÃŸe with a big sign.

name: Anonymous
comment: The access lane to the south is great towards Trier and Wittlich.

name: Anonymous
comment: Ramp 'HÃ¶rstel' towards OsnabrÃ¼ck. Walk along the BahnhofstraÃŸe, go left at the protestant church and follow the street until its end(1,5 km). At the end walk right and you'll see the highway.

name: Anonymous
comment: Take bus R51 or 16 to "Am Max-Klemens-Kanal". Get out and try standing before the railway crossing, there's lots of space. All cars going to Sprakel or Greven

name: Anonymous
comment: Direction: Heilbronn/Karlsruhe/North

name: Anonymous
comment: Direction: Aalen/Esslingen

name: Anonymous
comment:
very good place,for going to ulm and further A8 and A7.
directly at the Bus Station "Blutenburg". seldom used Bus station where cars can stop

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good place to find a lift to the Netherlands (trucks!) or to Osnabrück.
Bad for other directions southwards or northwards.

name: Anonymous
comment: Quite a good place to find a lift on the countryside highway to Vechta. You can ask the cars stopping at the traffic light or just stand next to the road with a sign or your thumb.

name: Anonymous
comment: there is a bus stop. very good spot to start hitchhiking from weimar, usally 15 to 30 minutes, theres also an gas station on the other side of the road to ask people directly.

name: Anonymous
comment:
good for munich, berlin, erfurt
take the bus 131 oder 131 and leave at the stop hollÃ¤ndische mÃ¼hle before the nova eventis center, good traffic

name: Anonymous
comment: Bad hitchhiking spot near Meerane, although if you find yourself stuck in the area it seems to be the best place to hitchhike from. However you really should consider taking a train to Zwickau or Chemnitz, and trying from one of those places instead. As you can see on the satellite image there is very little traffic on this road, but like anywhere you will get rides if you look desperate enough. I got a car to stop by doing an 'emergency' signal on the side of the road and holding out a sign with just a black arrow on it. To get here, walk from Meerane. For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/Meerane

name: Anonymous
comment: Terrible hitchhiking spot at Meerane. Meerane is way too quiet, and there is no long distance traffic here whatsoever. If you get stuck here, your best bet is to take a train to Zwickau or Chemnitz, or try your luck on the A4/B93 junction. As I was on the way to Poland and my driver did a 50km detour to here (all the way from the A9) because he was sure that dropping me off at Meerane's McDonalds was a good idea. He shouldn't have bothered. For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/Meerane

name: Anonymous
comment: Bushaltestelle hinter einer Kreuzung, sehr guter Spot

name: Anonymous
comment: Large motorway service station near Alsfeld, great for getting long-distance journeys in any direction. Average waiting time 30 minutes. Alsfeld is near the NE border of the RMV travelzone, so if you have a ticket giving you unlimited travel within this zone then here is a good place to start for journeys North or East out of Hessen. For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/Alsfeld

name: Anonymous
comment: Medium-sized motorway service station 'Teufelstal'. The south side of the services is excellent for getting rides North, South and East. I haven't tried the other direction yet, but it's probably good too. If you've been travelling east along the A4, this is a great place to get dropped off. Average waiting time 20-30 minutes. For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/A4_(Germany)

name: Anonymous
comment: Sliproad to the motorway. Average waiting time 30-60 minutes. Not a very bad spot, but there are better ones nearby. For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/KÃ¶ln

name: Anonymous
comment: You take the train to the station Hasselbrook, from this position you walk to the Sievekingsallee and turn left. The you will find a circle. Its the best Position, for making hitch hicking to Berlin and Lübeck. But you must stand their with a sign, where you displayed your aim.

name: Anonymous
comment: Large motorway services. Should be good, although I ended up waiting a few hours early on a Monday morning. If you're travelling south from DÃ¼sseldorf, consider starting from here (take a train to Hilden, then take bus 741 or walk through the suburbia). For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/DÃ¼sseldorf

name: Anonymous
comment: Busy petrol station, rides to the Netherlands available. Got a ride within seconds. Useful as a drop-off point when travelling from MÃ¼nster. For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/Steinfurt

name: Anonymous
comment: Walking along this road with a sign saying 'NL' got results within 5 minutes. I may have just got lucky, though. For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/MÃ¼nster

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus stop. Well-known hitchhiking spot, good for all directions out of Frankfurt. Get here with StraÃŸenbahn line 16 or 17, or U-Bahn line U4. Stop is 'Festhalle/Messe' (50m away on the other side of the roundabout). You often find other hitchhikers here, especially in the morning. Waiting time 30-60 minutes. For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/Frankfurt_am_Main

name: Anonymous
comment: Said to be a good spot, but from several hours of trying here I still haven't managed to get a lift. A much better spot is the bus stop on Theodor-Heuss-Allee. For more info, see http://www.hitchwiki.org/Frankfurt_am_Main

name: Anonymous
comment:
Going from Cottbus to Berlin / Dresden. Its close to one of the two accesses to the autobahn in Cottbus. cars come directly from the city.
Take tram nr 4 exit at \"Saarbrücker-straße\" and walk west along the the main road. you might see some autobahn signs as well. Anyway you have to walk like ten minutes until you see this bus stop in the beginning of the wood. Well there are busses going as well but i dont know which nr. But its ok  as well. Good Luck!

name: Anonymous
comment: You need a sign showing the direction you want to go or you can talk directly to the drivers at the traffic light.

name: Anonymous
comment: You can try this gas station to find a lift to Braunschweig or the autobahn A2.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Not a good gas station to find a lift to Hamburg. Many cars staying in the city.
Try the gas stations about 1 km to the north or pose yourself next to the street directly in front of the motorway.

name: Anonymous
comment: in direction Mainz it's excelent in direction Cologne it's bad

name: Anonymous
comment: It's easy to go on the A4 from here. You can reach this point by walking very easy. Driver can stop it is not the best place to stop, but it's also not to dangerus.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very much traffic here, great for both directions.

name: Anonymous
comment: depends on in which direction you want

name: Anonymous
comment: good place to go to the north (hamburg, rostock, baltic sea), last possibility to stop before the motorway

name: Anonymous
comment:
> A9

either bad luck or bad point, I got stuck there with a friend, following directions we found on a website. Definitely change hitching place!

name: Anonymous
comment: basic place to get to the highway (exit Piding / Bad Reichenhall)

name: Anonymous
comment: Really huge service area. Lots of polish cars.

name: Anonymous
comment: RaststÃ¤tte Goldene Bremm. Perfect for going to Metz, Paris, Strasbourg or even Spain on the one hand or to Nuernberg, Dresden, Leipzig or even Poland on the other hand. Can be easily reached from the bus station Neue Bremm.

name: Anonymous
comment: Rasthof Boerde - good for getting out of Magdeburg, but it is quite a waste of time to get there (take a bus to the nearest village and walk walk walk - id rather try the gas station in the town (also marked)

name: Anonymous
comment: Aral gas station on Magdeburger Ring for getting out of Magdeburg direction east or west

name: Anonymous
comment: Roundabout \"Europaplatz\" with direct exit to the motorway. Enough space for cars to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: Heidesheim petrol station, take the train to Heidesheim from Mainz (â‚¬3.40) and walk 1km to the Autobahn. Good for direction Koblenz and Ludwigshafen (A61)

name: Anonymous
comment: A really cool place for hitching.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good for hiking to Lindau and Switzerland

name: Anonymous
comment:
I was here on a Sunday and had to wait for 2 hours. Probably faster on a weekday.

To get there from Wuppertal, take the bus no. 618 or 624 to Lahmburger Str.
Then follow \"Gennebrecker Str.\" to north (5 minutes walking).

name: Anonymous
comment: Go to Metro Stop Studentenstadt-500 mtrs. Outbound Good for hiking to NÃ¼rnberg

name: Anonymous
comment:
gas station M.East - a lot of transit traffic, North, South, East! The way description:
Take the S-Bahn to the station \"Vaterstetten\", walk down the Bahnhofstreet, turn left and out of the city until you reach a traffic-circle where you have to turn left and after 1,5 km you reach the highway bridge where a path leads you to the rest stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus stop direction Rheine. Good to lift out of this village to Rheine or the A30 ramp.Bus only 2x a day to Rheine!

name: Anonymous
comment: gas station \"seeberg ost\", direction of Prenzlau, Hamburg, Rostock, Greifswald, baltic sea. For those who like to ask people excellent as well as for those waiting at the exit. good place to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: Petrol station "Lichtendorf", good to get a lift to Cologne, Leverkusen or Wuppertal!

name: Anonymous
comment: Parking area \"Königsforst\", not much traffic,got a lift to Frankfurt/Main there.Better try to get to the next gas station :-)

name: Anonymous
comment: Tankstation \"Plötzetal\", good if you want to go east to Halle/Saale, Leipzig or south towards Jena/Gera or Hof (Bayern)

name: Anonymous
comment: coming from the highway, heading inside magdeburg. Maybe you will be pickd up by an older man owning a plane at the nearby magdeburg airport. offers flight for free, happened once to me. bus stop, slow speed, excellent spot!

name: Anonymous
comment:
Direction: Leipzig, Halle, Magdeburg, Hanover, even GÃ¶ttingen

small gas station, but last resting place before leipzig. To be closed within a year from today. Not too much traffic but asking people helps you out

name: Anonymous
comment: Tankstation Auetal, Good to get lifts to Bielefeld, Hamm, Dortmund.Also the last tankstation if you want to go on the A30 to Osnabrück or the Netherlands.Watch out for yellow numberplates!

name: Anonymous
comment: Service station Lappwald. Amazing to get rides westwards to the Ruhr Area, Hannover, Braunschweig.

name: Anonymous
comment: Parking Area \"Emstal\".I'm always getting here when I travel from Hörstel. Good to get lifts to the Netherlands!Sometimes a lot of British people stopping here.Last parking before the Kreuz Schüttdorf A30/A31! So you have the chance to get north/west and south!

name: Anonymous
comment: Last exit before the Netherlands!A lot of Dutch people riding up here going west,also a number of people going to the next Dutch Citys Oldenzaal and Enschede

name: Anonymous
comment: Good to get lifts to Bad Oeynhausen, Hannover, maybe further A2 -> Berlin! Try to get a Polish truck! This is the first tankstation on the A30 when you're coming from the Netherlands!

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to hitch west towards the A31 or Netherlands. Cars have enough space to stop, there's a lot of traffic. And if you want, you can push the traffic light button so cars going towards the highway HAVE TO stop :-)

name: Anonymous
comment: Not much space to stop cars, no hard shoulder. Cars coming from 3 directions, so it's hard to ask. Maybe try it on the space under the bridge or at the nearby gas station. Not recommended to stand directly at the ramp.

name: Anonymous
comment:

name: Anonymous
comment: RaststÃ¤tte Wunnenstein is a great place to start. No matter if you want to go north or south.

comment:
Rasthof 'Dresdener Tor' (petrol station)
direction Chemnitz

name: Anonymous
comment: German-Polish border. Excellent place in both directions.

name: Anonymous

comment: Tryed to get on the A8 here today and as there is no good place to stop I wouldn't reccoment to try it. Besides no good place to stop there are two major things to consider - first a plus; manny cars go by; second - there are plenty directions where they could go, most likely not yours -.-

name: Anonymous

Direction Wittlich, Koblenz, Kaiserslautern, SaarbrÃ¼cken.
Ask for \"Verteilerkreis\", everybody knows where that is.
A bus stops there.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Very big service area. Great place when heading to Berlin or Dortmund.
To get there from Hannover, take the U4 to Garbsen, then transfer to Bus no. 126 to the last station (WaldschÃ¤nke).
This takes approx. 30 Minutes from central station.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good place when heading to Bremen (A1) or Hannover (A2).
To get there from Schwerte train station, take bus no. R50 to \"Lichtendorf Poetschke\". From there you can already see the service area.

name: Anonymous
comment: Rather small service area, but enough traffic to find a ride.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very big service area. Easy to get a ride here.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Great for Mayen, Trier, Luxemburg (A48).

name: Anonymous
comment: Almost no traffic here.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Petrolstation just before Dresden on A4 (position on map not accurate). 
Very poor for Prague (expect hours to wait, especially in evening), very good for Poland, good for Berlin.

name: Anonymous
comment: An excellent spot for going South and West. Get her by taking the regional train into direction Dessau, and get off at Michendorf for a walk of half an hour.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Get there by train S8, station \"schÃ¶neweide\".
Use the entrance to the (cheaper) \"jet\" gas station. 
Good and famous place to leave Berlin southwards (dresden, praha).

name: Anonymous
comment: no cars on this senseless little island. i had to walk!

name: Anonymous
comment:
Much traffic to south.
Don't use this place when heading to Trier (A48).

name: Anonymous
comment: Germany, (Poland), (Czech Republic).	Border A67. Bus 5 stop â€œJean Laudystraatâ€. 2000 m NE general direction from the bus stop.  40 mins from station Venlo. Restaurant on the motorway. Customs.

name: Anonymous
comment:
You can find the description \"how to get there\" at hitchbase.com.

Its the motorway entrance \"Schnellsen Nord\" northwards towards Kiel, Flensburg, Danmark. This place is illegal as you will have to cross the motorway-sign to have a good chance to get a lift.

name: Anonymous
comment: Its at a traffic-light. There are three lanes for cars going left directing the motorway (A215 leading to the A7) either northwards towards Danmark or southwards towards Hamburg, Hannover, Kassel etc.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Fuelstation \"Rasthof Kassel-West\"

Very good for southern direction

I have been here about 5 times and always got a lift within 20-30 minutes

comment:
Fuel Station \"Hamburg-Stillhorn\"

-probably good for: direction Bremen (A1) 

-worse: Southern direction (A7); we waited there for 2 hours

-also a lot of people who drive into the city

-take the bus line 13 from S-Bahn-station Wilhelmsburg to Kirchdorf-Süd

name: Anonymous
comment: I was there a few times, direction to WÃ¼rzburg. Worked quite well.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Direction A5 north and south.

It doesn't make sense to go here by tram from Freiburg centre, but if you're somewhere near it works pretty well. (There is a traffic light, so you can ask people who come from the Adelheid-Steinmann-StraÃŸe).
Tram stop is \"Rieselfeld\".

name: Anonymous
comment: I was lucky once, but the other times it took far too long until somebody stopped for the A5.

name: Anonymous
comment: direction leipzig, chemnitz

comment: direction berlin. good to reach, good for drivers to stop but sometimes difficulties with the police.

name: Anonymous
comment: direction Rostock, Hamburg, good space for cars to stop, A20 in reach

name: Anonymous
comment: diretion berlin, chemnitz

name: Anonymous
comment: direction lubmin, eldena - excellent bus stop

name: Anonymous
comment: works in direction of Dresden, Frankfurt, Praque, but a bit difficult because most drivers turn fast there

name: Anonymous
comment: at the traffic lights, many people stop on the right lane to turn right onto the A9

name: Anonymous
comment: fine to get a lift to the motorway. but first you have to get there.. good luck! :)

name: Anonymous
comment: Direction Kassel, Frankfurt, WÃ¼rzburg Everyone that stops can bring you to the next Fuel Station, 2 km south. This one is not that good, alas.

name: Anonymous
comment: Wait in the middle of the road for the red traffic light, then ask those who want to turn left for a lift to Kaufpark or Autobahn.

name: Anonymous
comment: very great place, especially on holidays.

name: Anonymous
comment: very big service area with a lot of traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Direction: Hannover and generally central Germany. Very nice place right next to the autobahn. Just make sure you stay before the blue sign (otherwise illegal) and don't stay behind the bridge pier. It's too dangerous and drivers see you too late.
How to get there:
Take the tram line no 1 to Dietrich BonhÃ¶ffer StraÃŸe. The station is south south west of the hitch point. Southwards trough the gardens until the next parallel street, then left to the station.
by polarfox (HC)

name: Anonymous
comment: asking for a ride on the machines to pay for the parking

name: Anonymous
comment:
Best place in town for hitching to north or south on the A61.
You can take the bus no. 013 or 023 to \"Vorster Stra

name: Anonymous
comment: not so much traffic, but enough to get a ride in a reasonable time.

name: Anonymous
comment: looks like a good position, but cars drive fast here, so its difficult for them to stop

name: Anonymous
comment: almost a perfect place for hitchhiking, when heading to the A8.

name: Anonymous
comment: only very few traffic here.

name: Anonymous
comment: There is also a gas station there where you can ask the drivers directly, but there are lots of cars to Wangen and A96, should be no problem...

name: Anonymous
comment: The Aral gas station directly at B3 direction South (Gießen, A5). If you're heading for the A4 (East) and feel short on time and traffic is low, consider taking the detour in the wrong direction on A5 to the rest station Wetterau, where you can reach the other side via a tunnel after the end of the parking area.

name: Anonymous
comment: gas station, not very many cars,most of them go towards munich

name: Anonymous
comment: habe hier viele touren angefangen, bin zuverlaessig innerhalb von 20-40 minuten mitgenommen worden.

name: Anonymous
comment: Fulda-Nord. Perfect spot to hh north via A7

name: Anonymous
comment: Only few cars passing by but stil the best spot in town to hh towards south via A7

name: Anonymous
comment: Ask people at gas station. Very good place to leave Karlsruhe in all directions ecept eastwards.

name: Anonymous
comment: Best place I could find to go eastwards on A38. On working days you can ask people at red light. I waited with a sign for 15 min on Saturday afternoon.

name: Anonymous
comment: Cars come slowly around the corner. Quickly got a lift towards the A4 to Dresden every of the four times I tried.

name: Anonymous
comment: Hitchhiking spot just behind the bridge (for cars to stop), if you want to get to Hörstel, get out at this ramp and hitch the last 3km. Pretty easy to get cars, though they drive a bit fast sometimes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very good sport to catch rides on the A44 westwards to Dortmund, Essen, Düsseldorf. We didn't wait more than 5min.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Directly at the gas station next to a McDonalds.
Stand here with a sign to get to the peage direction Metz

name: Anonymous
comment: To Bad Dürkheim or Neustadt (Weinstraße) this seems to be an agreable spot. Place yourself on empty parking lots. Better accept only longer rides to neustadt or bad dürkheim because there is a bypass road and if you get stuck in one of the villages it gets hard (but most of them have a trainstation)

name: Anonymous
comment: there is an ESSO petrol-station along A659 (eastward direction). you can reach A5 (via A659) within minutes. drivers at this place can take you to weinheim as well as heidelberg (south) or darmstadt (north) on A5. you can also ask just to get taken to another relais (petrol station) on A5. this station here is rather small. it is difficult to reach it from nearby 'rhein-neckar-zentrum'. take tram number 5 from the city center of mannheim to RHEIN-NECKAR-ZENTRUM (a shopping mall), walk on 'heidelberger straße' east, cross the autobahn over the bridge, and walk (illegal!) along it west towards the station again. it is possible, only 300 meters. on my personal rating from "1" to "10" ("1" very bad, "10" perfect) i will rate this spot a "7".

name: Anonymous
comment: a place to reach mannheim safely. there is a traffic light and many cars going through. it should not take longer than five minutes. reach this spot with tram number "5" direction "mannheim main station". get off near "RHEIN-NECKAR-ZENTRUM".

name: Anonymous
comment: an average place to stop cars. the better place: head in the direction of the large MANN MOBILIA XXXL furniture shop 300 meters (less than a minute walking). there is a taffic light where cars stop safely. build a sign with A5 on in as well as your destination such as 'heidelberg' or 'frankfurt' or 'freiburg' or 'basel'. on my personal rating this spot here on the intersection gets only a "6". too many cars pass by as there is no safe spot to stop for them.

name: Anonymous
comment: a perfectly safe place to catch drivers going north or south on autobahn A5. just find the MANN MOBILIA XXXL market, there is a restaurant inside in case you are hungry, they also sell coca-cola or water. it should not take longer than 10 minutes to find a driver that can take you to heidelberg/frankfurt or freiburg/basel. there is also a tram that brings you there in four minutes from the main station on karlsruhe.

name: Anonymous
comment: take the suburban train (s-bahn) from the city-center of freiburg to "schallstadt"-station (three or four stops). walk on "lindenstraße" westward out of town and change later on L187. it takes 30 minutes to reach the petrol station. there are plenty of cars stopping. you can find drivers that take you to karlsruhe, heidelberg, frankfurt, kassel or even hannover (A5/A7). do not forget to build a sign. "a 9 to 10" on my personal rating. a perfect spot. there is a restaurant as well.

name: Anonymous
comment: a place to reach DARMSTADT on B38. it takes only five minutes waiting time when i was standing there, close to "reinheim" DB station. the driver took me in 15 minutes to the city-center of darmstadt. you can also take the suburban train (DB RB-regional bahn) to darmstadt. the place is very safe. there is a traffic light so cars need to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment:
One can get to IKEA from Erlang by first taking tram 2 and then bus 80. Bus 80, however, comes once an hour or every 2 hours (depending on day/time ...) so make sure to get the right one!

Otherwise, it was easy to find people to get us on A71. However, I have to warn you that A71 has only *1* gas station and it might take a while to find someone to go that far!

name: Anonymous
comment: Even though close to A3 and has 2 gas stations on each side of the road, many people just go to nearby villages! Had no luck getting on A3... No public transport around. So one is pretty much screwed :)

name: Anonymous
comment: Bushaltestelle, richtung Pöttmes mit Bahnhof Aichach ziemlich in der Nähe; hab maximal ne viertelstunde gewartet und bin immer relativ gut weggekommen

name: Anonymous
comment:
to NL/Groningen with good chances to beat the slow train! 

Just walk towards this spot coming from Leer train station, the road has slow traffic all the way and you may find a ride even before you get to this spot.

name: Anonymous
comment: Traffic isle, good spot for NL/Groningen (and probably Germany, opposite ramp). Not a lot of traffic, but people see you from far and have to slow down to make the turn.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Gast station. Next gas station from Darmstadt.
Get here by bus:
Take the 5515 to Gräfenhausen-Am Rotböll. Turn around to face the Autobahn, go to the circle junction and turn right to the forest. When the road splits go left.

Direction: A5 North (Frankfurt, Kassel, Hannover, Berlin)

name: Anonymous
comment:
On-Ramp
A lot of cars drive by lowspeed due to traffic lights. Bad place to stop though.

name: Anonymous
comment: At end of town, there's a restaurant with sufficient space along the street to stop cars direction Hörstel.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good point to hitch away  and ti get on A71. Attention: there is only only one Gasstation on A71, and the parking places are rarely visited.

name: Anonymous
comment: At a parking lot exit. We waited a long time here but this is because most of the driver are going north (Koln, downtown) while we where heading south (Saarebruk). Several person stopped and we had to refuse their offer because of that. Drivers seems to react very well to us and showed friendly. For this I would say the stop is good.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good place for going in the direction of Kaiserslautern through A63. For Francfort through A63 best is to go to the other highway entrance on the other side of the town.

name: Anonymous
comment: This place is not so good. The signpost that mark the beginning of the highway is very close to the curve so you have to hitch after it which is illegal. Someone did however stopped and took us to Saarebrucken.

name: Anonymous
comment: Best place to stand when you wanna go to Kiel.

name: Anonymous
comment:
gasstation (aral). the best spot i know for getting out of cologne in western direction (a4 to aachen / netherlands), and to the highway service station frechen. also, many cars go to a61 northern or souhtern direction from here. asking people while they refuel worked best for me. 
public transport is ideal: U1 to Mohnstraße or Bahnweg.

name: Anonymous
comment: i tried to get a lift to denmark from here in the evening (9pm). stood on the big concrete square ca. 150 meters away from the terminal and just showed my thumb. after some cars that ignored me, someone stopped and took me onto the ferry for free and further to copenhagen.

name: Anonymous
comment: This spot is perfect if you are going west towards Hamburg. I asked 4 people and got a direct ride to Hamburg. Waiting time under 5 min!!!

name: Anonymous
comment: Cannot say anything good about this spot. It is very depressing to see over 600 cars an hour passing by and nobody takes you. The spot itself isn't that bad to hitchhike but the drivers that are driving to the highway are mostly driving on the left side and since this is a 3 lane road it is hard for them to pull over on to the right hand side. Maybe you'll have more luck! Waited almost 2 hours and then drove to Rasthof Stolper Heide, northwest of Berlin. Got a ride in 3 min there :-)

name: Anonymous
comment: I love it when hitchhiking goes fast. And this is a spot where it does go fast. First person I asked drove me northbound an the A9.

name: Anonymous
comment: Nice spot, lots of truck-drivers, and easy to get there from the city. Got a truck-ride within 10 min.

name: Anonymous
comment: Hitched twice from this spot. First time i didn't even had to ask people, a truck driver came towards me and asked where I was going to. Second time I started thumbing because of an other hitchhiker that was standing at the petrol station asking people. He gave me a sign when he got a ride and I was gone in no time after him, asking at the fuelstation.

name: Anonymous
comment: Hitchhiked twice from this spot. Experience: good to average. A lot of people are staying in the area or are going to Bremen. Good for the west average for the south. First time 20 min waiting time (west), second time little over an hour (south).

name: Anonymous
comment: A lot of traffic going through here. You can stay at the petrol station asking people. Good for Berlin, in my case it took about 20 min to get the ride to Berlin.

name: Anonymous
comment: If you need to get onto the E35 this is a very easy spot to get a ride. It's easy for cars to see you and to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: A bay mentioned in the article about Bad Oeynhausen. Perfect place to get a lift eastwards. Took us 5 mins to hitchhike a truck going straight to Poland.

name: Anonymous
comment: I thought it was a bad place, but within five minutes I got Mercedes SLK to Leipzig. You can also get here a car to another southern cities.

name: Anonymous
comment: not legal, but you can stop direction munich

name: Anonymous
comment:
A ramp near ikea. It's in a walking distance from S-Bahn Eching, you can take a bus here as well.
Almost all of the cars are local (i.e. Freising). Might take long time to get a good ride.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot for going direction Ingolstadt. There is a gas station, so you can talk to people. But it was the road that worked for us. Got a ride to Munich in no time.

name: Anonymous
comment: This  gas station is suggested in the wiki page, but it's better you don't go there :) It's hidden from the main road, so only locals moving inside Berlin go there, a lot of taxi driver, and it's also an expensive gas station. I needed 3 hours to find a ride south

name: Anonymous
comment: Against expectations this is not a bad spot at all to go north.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Raststätte Wittstock/Dosse

Berlin--North
  Last one before turning towards Rostock.

name: Anonymous
comment: Melle-Ost on-ramp, roundabout with sufficient space on the exit towards the highway, great for getting rides to the service station 3km ahead or further (Bad Oeynhausen). Traffic drives slow.

name: Anonymous
comment: Sufficient hard shoulder to stand on, but extremely low traffic on this on-ramp.

name: Anonymous
comment: Great on-ramp for direction Osnabrück. Sufficient hard shoulder, lots of traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment: Fairly good starting point to hitch towards the highways. There is a traffic light with a small street right after where cars can stop for a moment. Use a sign saying A3.

name: Anonymous
comment: Had to wait 15 minutes to get a lift to Grünberg. the cars are allowed to drive 50km/h and have enough space to stop for you. good luck!

name: Anonymous
comment: Marienborn service area. Very easy to find a lift to Poland as many truckers stop there. Moreover, this spot used to be one of the major border crossings between West and East Germany since 1945 till 1990. The whole infrastructure has been preserved, so if you are interested in history, you might consider spending some more time here for sightseeing.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Direction: Berlin
Not a very good place, not many cars going to Berlin - for best effects stand just by the lane, lots of cars move just through B98

name: Anonymous
comment: Nice spot because there's a traffic light and cars get a good look at you before pulling directly onto the highway going west. I had to wait almost 15 seconds for a ride.

name: Anonymous
comment: Not enough space for cars to stop and quite fast traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment: Even if hiking from McDonalds can cause some problems, then the petrol station 200m farther is a very good place to hike towards Poland.

name: Anonymous
comment:
In principle it's legal, and in principle there's loads of traffic and a lot of place for cars to stop. In practice bored cops will send you away.
But if you're fast...

name: Anonymous
comment: No possibility to get a lift to the south!

name: Anonymous
comment: We asked a driver at the red ligth to take us to Salzburg.

name: Anonymous
comment: A good spot to get to Weimar, if you get up early enough to catch the commuters. There are some parking lots at the sidewalk. The lady who took me, told me that there are often hitchhikers.

name: Anonymous
comment: Actually I didn't catch a ride from here, but that was because I was going into the wrong direction (I wanted to go east/ A2). If you want to get to the A3 to the north, that might be a good place to ask for rides.

name: Anonymous
comment: If somebody tells you to go from Memmingen direction Lindau this way - don't believe them. It's a rather bad spot. I waited around 1-1,5 hours to get to the next rest area, which is on the wrong side of the highway and wasn't very cool either.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good place to get on A95 direction Garmisch-Partenkirchen. You can get here with U3. There is also a bus 56 from Pasing, or the same one from Blutenburg, right next to the end of A8. 

Keep in mind, there is only rest area before Garmisch, near Höhenrain.

name: Anonymous
comment: Lots of cars going to the North. Almost everybody going south aren't going far, and they are relatively few.

name: Anonymous
comment:
I hichhiked here to go to Szczecin (Stettin); quite remote place, but if you find a lift to this place it's not so bad: there is a traffic light, so cars slow down a bit more. As you see from the arrows, you catch all the cars coming from the city and from both directions of the Berliner ring.
The remoteness of the place, then, stimulates car drivers to stop, because they'll think there's something wrong if a person walks on that road.

name: Anonymous
comment: I hitch-hiked here to go to Szczecin (Stettin). In general, I don't recommend to use the thumb on the Berliner Allee; to much traffic, few places to stop, nervous people, and you're still inside the town. Exactly in the spot I put there is a petrol station; it's on the other side of the street and people going to Poland usually wait to be there to refuel because it's cheaper, but anyway it's better than the thumb. So, few cars directed to Szczecin, but some of them anyway going out from Berlin in direction North (ask for Bernau too); once you're on the Autobahn (in petrol stations!) or also in the countryside it's easier to find somebody.

name: Anonymous
comment: I tried to hitchhike from here to Szczecin (Stettin), but it didn't work. There is a petrol station, but few cars stop here to refuel and it is on the other side of the street. I suggest you to walk a bit and go to the cross between B2 and Berliner Ring, it's much better.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Weeze Airport (NRN), past exit of P2, toward Cologne, Netherlands.

Plenty of cars passing by, many packed with families returning from holiday. Also drivers who have just dropped someone off.
Enough space for stopping.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Weeze, A57 (both Cologne and Netherlands).

Bus stop kind of asphalt strip next to the road (though no actual stop here!). Try to get dropped off here from Weeze airport if your initial ride is headed the opposite direction on the highway.

name: Anonymous
comment: thought this might be a good spot...many students, and as it was a Friday I thought perhaps some of them would be leaving home...but forget it! this place is dead, as is the whole areal (when it comes to car traffic ofc). also, don't try to stand on the main road b/c it is huge!

name: Anonymous
comment: at the beginning I thought this might be a good spot, as it leads rights out of the city centre, but mostly b/c I used to take carsharing offers which usually start at the west entrance of the Hbf yet I couldn't see where cars should stop along the street, b/c it is quite well frequented, so I didn't try; if you're heading to Trier, perhaps consider leaving from Wiesbaden instead

name: Anonymous
comment: Senseless! Relatively little traffic and no place for cars to stop. Instead, take the bus in the direction of Wiesbaden Hbf and get off at the very next bus stop (Freibad; see other post)!

name: Anonymous
comment: Finally a perfect spot! :) LOTS of traffic and all leading out of the city onto the A66! It's a 2-lane road, but you got a bus stop right behind you for cars to pull over. B/c of traffic lights it's easy to jump into any car. In my case, a guy on the 2nd lane stopped and I had enough time to get in.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very little traffic, but chances are the drivers will either drive to Frankfurt or Trier... better chances than at the airport b/c single drivers. After standing at the airport for 1 1/2 hrs, got a ride here after 5 min...

name: Anonymous
comment:
After waiting around 1 hour in every other corner in this area, we came here. There is a 1.5 meter wide grass patch between the 2 lanes. Cars going on A8 will take the 2 inner lanes (lanes towards the middle) and have plenty of time to see your sign. Also there is plenty of time to get on board.
I don't know about legal issues.
Don't forget to smile :D

name: Anonymous
comment: Place to hitchhike South to Wurzburg, Ingolstadt or Munich.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Wesel

name: Anonymous
comment: Exit no. 30 from Berliner Ring. Didn't take long to find a ride to Hamburg. Probably a good place to ask your driver to drop you, if they're going in a different direction.

name: Anonymous
comment:
You can get here by U-Bahn 12 from the center of Köln, then just walk across the field.
I was trying to get to Hanover, and during one hour of waiting I've stopped about 7 cars before one finally took me to Leverkusen, from where it was easier.

name: Anonymous
comment: Cars going to Dresden use the left lane and don't stop...

name: Anonymous
comment: useless to berlin : prefer go back to dresden and begin from there

name: Anonymous
comment: useless to berlin : prefer go back to dresden and begin from there

name: Anonymous
comment: McDonald's restaurant and petrol station. Quite a few Polish cars if you wanna head to Poland or East in general.

name: Anonymous
comment: got a hitch after five seconds with a truck driver to praha with two guys!

name: Anonymous
comment:
A real good station for going west in direction of Chemnitz or Leipzig but also other destiations like magdeburg, hanover, köln, stuttgart, nürnberg, ...
but for the begin its always better to ask only for the direction because its easyer to tramp from rest stop to rest stop

name: Anonymous
comment: You should only ask the people before they go to pay the fuel and than its realy easy to get a lift in the direction of berlin! we wait only 5 minutes for 2 places and a lot of bagguage

name: Anonymous
comment: pretty good place to get a ride southwards. a lot of people come from the ferry. you can ask them directly, when they fill up their gas.

name: Anonymous
comment: Motorcar road on-ramp in the direction of Ulm and to the motorway to München. If you really want to hitchhike from here, this is possibly the only good spot to do so.

name: Anonymous
comment: Check the other spot at Berkheimer Straße if you want to go in the direction of Ulm - this spot is senseless because it is impossible for cars to stop here.

name: Anonymous
comment: You can reach this service station easily by public transport from Esslingen. It's possibly a good hitchhiking spot when they finished rebuilding it.

name: Anonymous
comment: waited there about 30 minutes on a sunday afternoon with not much traffic in directio of Dortmund. Probably a lot better during the week. Not far from the S-Bahn station Köln-Longerich (10 min walk). Cars a slow because of the traffic light and enough space on the side of the road for cars to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: From here you can hitch a ride only in direktion noth (Dortmund). Stod there on a sunday with not much traffic and waited 30 min. During the week there sould be a lot more cars coming by because of the big shopping centre. Good spot to get to the next pertrol station (Remscheid) on the Autobahn.

name: Anonymous
comment: For going to Nederland or Emden, Leer it is good place, cars are not so fast and there is place to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: Gas station "Hasselberg". A ton of cars to all different directions.

name: Anonymous
comment: Most the cars are going to the Ruhrgebiet. I got a ride to Bremen with a friend after a while.

name: Anonymous
comment: You can show your sign to cars from both directions. There is a hard shoulder so that cars can stop. Nevertheless, out of many cars only few stop.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Gas station; direction north
It's possible to get to A49/Kassel from here, but there's also a lot of local traffic (I guess especially mid-week). It might take a while if you're unlucky.

name: Anonymous
comment: A very nice place to get to the north/cologne. Enough space to stop and a lot of slow cars

name: Anonymous
comment: it is good to go to the next gas station on the highway. there is a traffic light and you have better chances by the afternoon when the people are done with working

name: Anonymous
comment: Service area "Göttingen West", direction south. Nearly everyone could take you to Kassel at least.

name: Anonymous
comment: Service area, directions Munich, Nürnberg, Regensburg, Stuttgart, Zürich etc. I once tried to get away in the Stuttgart/Augsburg direction, which didn't work very fast. Getting to Munich city or Nürnberg would have been really easy.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Rastplatz Hohenlohe Nord

Hitchhiking on Sunday, August 28th was very hard (had to stay overnight) cause cars were full with traveling families and trucks are not allowed to operate on Sundays (except for freezers). However, this place is in the nice area and with plenty of space for camping at the back of the station. I recommend to talk with truck drivers - a lot of them are going to France and willing to take travelers.

name: Anonymous
comment: Not a good spot, far from motorway, few cars and many of them local. I ended up there because driver thought that it is the  BAB Frankenhole Nord station which in reality is some 20 km further and this place is not on the map (at least not on mine) so it is possible to take this for other one. I was there on Saturday and it took me some 4h to get from there to west. A lot of place for camping though, that could be useful if you end up in this spot :)

name: Anonymous
comment:
Bus stop, direction A81(north)/Unterjesingen.
I tried it once and in (my) theory this was the perfect spot, but it took me 3 h to get to the near service area "Schönbuch" at the motorway. A local told me that many people rather take the other routes via B464 to Böblingen and B27 to Stuttgart.

name: Anonymous
comment: not much traffic at that on-ramp, had a lot luck only waited 30min to get a lift to Gießen (a5). if u come frome the north it might be better to get off one gasstation earlier, called "Hasselberg"

name: Anonymous
comment: motorway service area "Utrichtshausen" with Gasstation and Restaurant. Easy to go direction north. There are already some drivers going to Hamburg.

name: Anonymous
comment:
AGIP petrol station. Good for westbound traffic on the A 2.
Friendly staff, very easy to reach with the tram (station "Albert Vater Str.) and they play nice music whilst you wait here. Good for asking people as well as for pulling people out with a sign on the kerbside.
Waited less than 30 mins even after 20.30h

name: Anonymous
comment: It was our first hiking trip and our driver brought us here, because we wanted to go south or west and he changed north at "Hermsdorfer Kreuz". Found somebody to Ingolstadt (A9) but we should have jumped out more in the north at Raststätte "Osterfeld", where you can change to the southbound side. But many cars came here. Idea: If you're stuck here try to get a lift from a local along the "Rodaer Straße" and walk onto the Rasthof in the south of the Hermsdorfer Kreuz (or a lift to Mörsdorf if you need another direction).

name: Anonymous
comment: a very good place if you want to go to berlin. a bad place if you want to go to dresden. only the truckdrivers will take you. so if its not a problem for you start here. good luck!

name: Anonymous
comment: the best place to start! you will not stay longer then 10 minutes. many people take a breake here who will drive to berlin or dresden.

name: Anonymous
comment: its ok if you want to go to berlin. very bad position for hitchhiking to dresden - scarcely anybody will stop here. maybe you have to be a darling of fortune? good luck!

name: Anonymous
comment: A lot of traffic, a lot of space, restaurant and shops.... People  who live in France and work in Freiburg do cross the boarder here. People from France come to get tabacco because its cheaper in Germany.

name: Anonymous
comment: There is a roundabout with a parkind area. You can walk from "Trossingen Bahnhof" to there in 10 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: It is a petrol station and a good place to go in directions Villingen

name: Anonymous
comment: We waited more than one hour to get to Aschaffenburg, but no one gave us a lift. Fortunately, the station is nearby.

name: Anonymous
comment: It's a Aral gas station. Good place to get to the A70 towards Schweinfurt or to the reverse direction of the A70, to the A9.

name: Anonymous
comment: More than 30 minutes of waiting in the rainy dark and no one gave me a lift towards Nuremberg.

name: Anonymous
comment: After 30 or 40 minutes, we decided to go by train, because no one gave us a lift towards Bamberg.

name: Anonymous
comment:
There's am Autohof just off the Autobahn with an Aral gas station and a McDonalds. Tried to get a ride south on A39 but it was rather pointless. If your going south try to get a ride at Helmstedt Nord, it's the gas station prior to that if your comming from east.
If you cant get a ride at the Autohof just walk towards the Autobahn and position yourself a the roundabout, got a ride within 10min.

name: Anonymous
comment: i´ve been waiting here for more than a half hour to get a lift to the highway but i couldn´t find anybody. after a while a guy from the gas station came over and asked me to leave:/ i think the distance to the highway (7km) makes it difficult to get a ride there. but maybe i was just unlucky

name: Anonymous
comment: Petrol station with restaurant, tabak and rest area (large parking lot). Took me a little while on a cold rainy day to go to Salzburg. But if you're going to Italy the place is great! Most truckers are going there through Innsbruck and many people going south stop to eat, get smokes, etc. Try asking around the trucks. The hitchhiker I met there found a ride to Innsburck in 15 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very good place for hitching a ride to Berlin.

name: Anonymous
comment: Just a parking lot, but quiet busy. Unfortunately most people are going to Hanover and Berlin. If you want to go to the north ask for a ride to the first ramp on the A1.

name: Anonymous
comment: Easy for cars to see you, hard and dangerous for them to stop. Further north is not much better either, since cars going to B1/A44/A1 will switch to left lane early. Asking people at the airport/catching people coming from Airport parking may work better (but check arrival times, no flights at some hours!)

name: Anonymous
comment: Good hitchhiking spot, a lot of trucks and cars going in direction to the Czech republic and further to the east

name: Anonymous
comment: Petrol station with cars going mostly east-west direction. Quite easy to get a lift to Heilbronn or Mannheim.

name: Anonymous
comment: Gas station with a lot of traffic going to the Koblenz, Köln, Aachen and Netherlands. There is also possible to camp.

name: Anonymous
comment: Petrol station located on the highway exit and maybe because of this obfuscated position together with bad visibility, not a lot of cars are going trough.

name: Anonymous
comment: Average spot at the traffic lights (for those who drive towards Schweinfurt onto the A70).

name: Anonymous
comment: There is a service area where you can also meet truck drivers to get further to Schweinfurt and tehn to the A7 towards Fulda. I did it several times, very successful.

name: Anonymous
comment: Aral petrol station, had no problems at all.

name: Anonymous
comment:
a good place on B185 between 
dessau and 'gartenreich wörlitz' which also connects you with leipzig (on A9,  southern direction) and berlin (A9, northern direction). there is a traffic light at this spot, cars have to stop every two minutes. a petrol station is nearby in case you are hungry/thirsty. you can reach the city center of dessau in less than 5 minutes from here.

name: Anonymous
