comment: one of berlins good places to leave the city. from the center of berlin, you reach the relais (rastanlage) with the s-bahn indicating 'potsdam' or 'wannsee', get off at nikolassee station. the walk takes less than two minutes. there is a traffic light as well as a petrol station and restaurant. many drivers go south on A 115 which can alternatively take you to 'rastanlage michendorf' (10 minutes) on 'berliner ring' where the situation for hitchhikers is even better. from michendorf it should not take longer than 10 minutes to find a driver to hannover, dessau (A8), leipzig (A8) or even munich (A8).

name: Anonymous
comment: Gas station, direction north to Kassel, A7, A44

name: Anonymous
comment: I got dropped off here, even after asking the driver to leave me at a resthof on the autobahn. Ick. This spot is NOT GOOD. There's no space for cars to stop, it's loud and chaotic, etc. Don't bother.

name: Anonymous
comment: I'm not exactly sure what I should put here... I got a ride in about 5 minutes with a sign that said, 'A5 Nord.'  There's a stoplight that backs up traffic for 1/3km, so you have a chance to look at nearly every driver in the eye to make sure they've seen you.  I got a lift very fast, but it could have been luck.

name: Anonymous
comment: Cars are going too fast here, and they divide between north, south, heaven and hell.  No place to stop unless there are now parked cars (and they are always there).

name: Anonymous
comment:
On the road after the jet. Fine place for north-sea rides and the BMW/Audi types of businessmen - Have sign, they will stop even if the place doesn't invite it.
Traffic worth it after 11:00.
North: HRO, HH, Dänemark etc.

name: Anonymous
comment: There is an Aral gasstation connecting directly with the A2 to go east. So maybe there are cars going to Berlin etc. Take the local train to Jadekamp stop and walk the rest of the way.

name: Anonymous
comment: http://hitchwiki.org/en/Berlin#Sch.C3.B6neweide

name: Anonymous
comment: in three minutes i hitch a car to Czech border. if you wait a little bit you can find a car to Prague.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Gasstation

Heading North on A7 you can catch a lift to "Rasthaus und Hotel Seligweiler" besides the A8 or directly towards Heidenheim on A7, where you pass the gasstation Lonetal.

I just waited 5 minutes on a Friday afternoon.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very sweet spot to get to Stuttgart on the B27. Traffic lights, so many cars are able to recognize you and plenty of space to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: Fuel station Bühleck towards east: quite some traffic, good place to get the next lift. Also easy to walk on from the town as there is a road and no fences.

name: Anonymous
comment: As of December 2011 this is the only highway fuel station along the A38. The A38 is generally not as crowded as the A4 but this also means a lot less accidents and traffic jams. As there are so few fuel stations chances are good you won't be waiting here for long. Recommended.

name: Anonymous
comment: a good place to find drivers on A9 north as well as southbound, direction leipzig and berlin as well as nuremberg and munich. there is a traffic light and enough cars and trucks passing by. a nearby petrol station (aral) at 'schwabenweg' is not to recommend, only local traffic stops there. from this place you can also reach weissenfels by car within five minutes. at gewerbegebiet kaethe-kollwitz-strasse (ten minutes west, walking) there is a mcdonalds restaurant.

name: Anonymous
comment: an aral petrol station with enough traffic to reach leipzig with a waiting time less than five minutes. take tram 1 to 'auessere horndorfer strasse', cross the street = there you are.

name: Anonymous
comment: 'rastanlage auerswalder blick' is a good option to travel west- or estward on A4, direction 'hermsdorfer kreuz' (west, you can change from that relais/rastanlage to all directions) or east, towards dresden and the german-polish border. rastanlage auerswalder blick you can reach by bus from the city center of chemnitz and a short walk of 20 minutes. a tunnel 500 meters west of the relais (or a bridge another 500 meters further) lets you change the sides of the autobahn.

name: Anonymous
comment: rasthof/relais 'hermsdorfer kreuz' is maybe one of the best german places to start or intermediate your journey. there is plenty of traffic 24 hours/7 days a week. a restaurant as well as a snack bar make this place very convenient. from here nonstop hitchhikes even to denmark or poland should be possible. a footunnel (300 meters north of the petrol station) connects the eastern part of the rastanlage with the western portion. waiting times for a trip to berlin are around 15 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Nice place to continue towards cologne or probably Frankfurt. Some people will go via A45 and A4, others will take the B49 and A3 afterwards. Both possibilities are fine.

name: Anonymous
comment: Highway fuel station named "Montabaur", there is traffic going from here to the A3 and A61 towards north. It's location is a tiny bit more complicated because it is combined with a highway exit. The traffic going here seems fine, though.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Eifel, Roetgen, Monschau and so on. Good place at the bus stop to stop, with light.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Direction Hamburg.

Exit of a Petrolstation and Burger King at the main road which passes into the motorway to hamburg. There is a trafficlight too, so drivers on the road see you as well. 
With a "HH-sign" i waited 3 minutes and got a very nice lift. 

Good luck!

name: Anonymous
comment: On-ramp in direction of Belgium. You can either thumb the vehicles down coming from Aachen centre that turn right here (mostly cars) or the cars coming straight from the opposite industrial area (cars and trucks).

name: Anonymous
comment: There is some traffic going to the Netherlands via the A4 from here. Two petrol stations, traffic lights and a bus stop for cars to pick you up. Take buses 27, 37, 47, 77 or 147 to stop "Jupp-Müller-Straße" from Aachen Bushof (main bus station).

name: Anonymous
comment: Fuel station and fast food restaurants near the highway.

name: Anonymous
comment: Service station "Aachener Land Süd" (formerly known as "Propsteier Wald") on the A4 in direction of Cologne. See Aachen hitchwiki for informations how to get here.

name: Anonymous
comment: A395 towards Vienenburg. You might be lucky holding a sign here, but in general not the best stop to get out of Wolfenbüttel. It's the closest from the train station however.

name: Anonymous
comment:
THIS is the aral gas station. I used this place several time to get out of Freiburg. You can easily reach it by taking tram #1 and hop off at Brauerei Ganther.
Both directions (south to Switzerland and north to Karlsruhe and Frankfurt) are possible there! Just talk to the people when they fill up their car. Good luck!

name: Anonymous
comment: I was heading towards the east along the A94 waiting at the highway entrance. It took me hours from this place to get away, very few cars passing by, a lot less were stopping. Mostly local people just going a couple of kilometres. As soon as I was on the A94 things worked fantastic. So patiences necessary here!

name: Anonymous
comment: There's a bus stop at the verge where people easily can stop. Years ago when I live in Rotenburg I always used this spot for local hitch-hiking. But also to get to a highway in direction to Hamburg e.g. it's a good spot, easy to get away.

name: Anonymous
comment: Gas station called Neubucher Stadt, on the way to Lubeck. The gas station looks all right, there are a few trucks, but no one travels further than Lubeck. We spent there around 15 hours and in total, there were maybe 50 cars that stopped, almost all of them locals. Ended up begging for a lift to Lubeck and then hitchhiking on the ramp in Lubeck to continue to Hamburg.

name: Anonymous
comment: I had one guy stop right away to take me into Berlin but then I made a sign for CB and got a ride with an older couple going right there

name: Anonymous
comment: Highway service station "Weilbach" on the A66 towards Frankfurt centre and Gießen.

name: Anonymous
comment: Highway service station "Frankfurt a. M." on the A66 towards Frankfurt centre and Gießen.

name: Anonymous
comment: Highway service station "Frankfurt a. M." on the A66 towards Mainz and Wiesbaden.

name: Anonymous
comment: Highway service station "Berfa" on the A5 towards Gießen. There is only a small parking lot on the opposite side of the highway.

name: Anonymous
comment: Cars coming from Ilmenau going to the A71 can see you from the traffic lights and have a small space to stop for you.

name: Anonymous
comment: About two dozen trucks stop over in the industrial area for the weekend break. If you're leaving early on monday finding a ride might be possible.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Autobahn service station "Rhynern Nord" on the A2 towards Ruhrpott, Cologne, NL and Belgium.

Has a fuel station, restaurant and hotel. There is a service station at the opposite side of the autobahn.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Autobahn service station "Lehrter See" on the A2 towards Magdeburg and Berlin.

There is no fuel station here, just a restaurant. There is a bridge to cross to the other side of the autobahn.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Rasthof (Autohof) "Magdeburg" off the autobahn A2.

You can get here by getting a lift out of Magdeburg on the B1 until Irxleben and walk the rest.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good spot to hitch cars from south direction towards Magdeburg on the B1 as they have to stop. Cars on the B1 are too fast to stop.

You can walk from/to the service station "Börde"on the A2 from here.

name: Anonymous
comment: Traffic light on the B1 towards Magdeburg. You can talk to drivers here. No place to stop if the traffic light is green.

name: Anonymous
comment: Traffic light for cars coming from the autobahn A2 towards the eastern part of Magdeburg.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Autobahn Service station "Medenbach Ost" on the A3 towards Cologne.

There is a petrol station and a restaurant. Getting to the opposite side is a 20 minute walk.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Autobahn service station "Heiligenroth" on the A3 towards Frankfurt. There is a petrol station, a restaurant and a motel.

The service station at the other side is called "Montabaur" and can be reached by walking back about 20 minutes in the direction you came from.

name: Anonymous
comment: Autobahn service station "Fernthal West" on the A3 towards Frankfurt. There is a petrol station and a restaurant.

name: Anonymous
comment: Am Fichtenplan Nord, A10. It seems that most cars here are locals going into Berlin after refilling fuel. The best from here is to get a short ride to the next station Michendorf, where there's a lot more long distance traffic, both to Magdeburg/Hannover as well as Leipzig.

name: Anonymous
comment: to Hamburg

name: Anonymous
comment: Very nice point to Kiel.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good spot out of Lüneburg to Hamburg. Traffic okay. 

Guter Punkt Richtung Norden. Verkehr ist okay, breiter Seitenstreifen zum Anhalten.

name: Anonymous
comment: A fuelstation (Aral) near the Motorway A14

name: Anonymous
comment: I was here by a mistake from the guy who gave me a lift. But it just took about 30 minutes to find a new lift in the direction of Leipzig.

name: Anonymous
comment: Resting place Muldental. Here is a patrol station and a fast food restaurant. It is the last big stop before Leipzig. From here you find people who want to go to north/south on the A9 or keep heading west.

name: Anonymous
comment: Gas Station near the Highway. we didn´t had any luck here, though, because most of them were only locals.

name: Anonymous
comment: to Mendig, A48, A61 or North to the Villages. Much traffic on sunday's, during Holidays or on sunny days. Long lifts possible.

name: Anonymous
comment: on-ramp 2 Alsfeld Ost on the A5. Good for rides in direction Kassel

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot if you just want to go on the other side of the Rhein, but very hard to get in the direction of Cologne.

name: Anonymous
comment: gasstation!

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to the Highway or even further (BERLIN). Cars can stop there easily!

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to Berlin. Got a hitch after 8min in the darkness :))

name: Anonymous
comment: Don't get your thumbs out fellows! Ask at the traffic light. Easy :)

name: Anonymous
comment: Resting Area with gas station "Rohrbrunn". Quite some traffic. Good possibilities to find a ride to Frankfurt. Also some drivers going west, maybe north as well.

name: Anonymous
comment: Service area and gas station "Irschenberg". Its off the Motorway and only one for both directions (east/south and westt/north).

name: Anonymous
comment:
Direction Koblenz
medium traffic

name: Anonymous
comment: Eichelborn Nord. Big gas station where many drivers take a break. Perfect spot to get into direction Bad Hersfeld (Frankfurt).

name: Anonymous
comment: I´ve never hiked from this place, but since i´m originally from schwandorf and have some hitchhiking experience i would propose this location. here is a new gas station right in front of the highway. since i think the best way to hichhike is to talk to people directly this should be the best place. good luck

name: Anonymous
comment: excellent spot (i'm living close by). stand before the advertising collum and the yield sign but behind the lights if you want to travel north.enough room to stop. no sign but big smile needed.best time on fridays is from 9.30am till13.30 pm.

name: Anonymous
comment: excellent for going north, there is some gravel at the side, where cars can stop. to most rides go to schweinfurt, change ride at the next gasstation (Riedener Wald) ca. 20km north from this point. best position is at the first black/white mark.

name: Anonymous
comment: fairly okay when you we're just dropped off from the autobahn and want to go north. be aware of the hausfrauenverkehr (after 19 pm you are stuck)

name: Anonymous
comment: Gasstation (Esso) near the highway A9 (North-South).

name: Anonymous
comment: we stand here for a half a hour - then go to south gas station

name: Anonymous
comment: Spot to Berlin from Greifswald with a sign. Small place for cars to stop, you get almost all the traffic from Greifswald.

name: Anonymous
comment: Lots of cars going to North, but possible to find also lifts to south. Good for trucks, too. Walkable from the airport.

name: Anonymous
comment: One of the better on-ramps: Cars are exiting the roundabout, so they are going low speed.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to hitchhike to the A5 (north). You definitely need a sign! Hitchhike just before the entrance to the Lidl.

name: Anonymous
comment: Best spot in Hamburg for heading to Berlin. Just stand in front of the busstop in direction to the roundabout. Doesn't take longer than 10 minutes waiting, even in the rain. Sometimes you even get company by other hitchhikers heading to Berlin.

name: Anonymous
comment: People get here to get cheaper gasoline than at the Autobahn A24. So possible to get a lift to Berlin or Hamburg. Nice chat with the service staff.

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus stop in drection to Autobahn A24. On the other side is a snack, sometimes trucker stay there.

name: Anonymous
comment: Motorway service area. Gas station with a diner behind.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Hamburg. Last gas station before the motorway to Hamburg.

name: Anonymous
comment: A gas station before people get on the motorway up to the North. Easy to reach by tram.

name: Anonymous
comment: On Ramp Brandenburg, good for Berlin, average to good to the West (Hannover) ... I'll give it an average, because there is no public transport close by.

name: Anonymous
comment: good point for city step to Erfurt mfg ew

name: Anonymous
comment: Spot on the sidewalk where people can stop. Not the best spot, but works pretty good. A lot of traffic going past, a good place to start north, south or east

name: Anonymous
comment: Just behind the Aral gas-station(maybe Esso, not sure any more) is a bus stop. its right at the beginng of the two lanes part, so a good place to stop for cars.

name: Anonymous
comment: Enough space at the on-ramp for hitchhiking rides towards Gronau, Enschede (Netherlands)

name: Anonymous
comment: One can only access the highway by taking the stairs at the viaduct which runs over the Dietrichsweg. You have to enter the highway, and stand behind the rail. We got a ride to Leer from here - but my opinion: It's too dangerous, besides, you don't want to get problems with the police.

name: Anonymous
comment: There's enough room for cars to stop here. The police would'n let us stand closer to the highwat, so you'll have to stand by the Neuschanzer Strasse.

name: Anonymous
comment:
petrol station on the B16 towards Regensburg, Kehlheim..tried it once. didnt work well. many local costumers.
anyway, the spot is situated quite well. if youre  lucky youu can catch a ride to the A9 as well. reachable by bus 44 and 11

name: Anonymous
comment:
Petrol station Köschinger Forst.
take bus 30 towards Hepberg/Lenting, get off at Römerstr, from there you have to walk about 10-15 min. Bus 30 doenst allways serve till Hepberg, Römerstrasse( check on http://www.invg.de/fahrplan/2012/30_2012.pdf) otherwise get off final station in Lenting. from there its  ten more additional walking minuts

name: Anonymous
comment: This Petrol Station is great for hitch-hiking from Berlin to Hamburg. There are many cars going to HH. I hitch-hike there on May 2012.

name: Anonymous
comment: This Petrol Station is the best point for going Bremen or somewhere else in South.

name: Anonymous
comment: The traffic is not high in here but it's good spot to go to Hannover direction.

name: Anonymous
comment: I spent here amost 2 hours, but i couldn't hitch any car to Berlin or Magdeburg. waiting here is senseless

name: Anonymous
comment:
Average rest area with just a WC. From my point of view a very good spot to get from Leipzig to any westbound destination. For near and easy things like Kassel or Göttingen or more advantageous aims like Southern Netherlands or Northern France this could be a gould start. The A 38 is from my experience a good connection to the west: very few congestions but still enough traffic to get away.

How to get there:
Take a train from Leipzig Central Station to Liebertwolkwitz Station (takes 15mins) and then just walk there (takes 20-30 mins) via "Großpösnaer Straße". Important note: This section of the Autobahn is fenced like many others. To finally acces the Rastplatz you either need to climb the fence (quite manageable) or bring tools.
As soon as I reached the area, I had a lift within 15 mins in sunday calm traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment: Towards Magdeburg ... after the bridge cars go slow and there is some space to stop

name: Anonymous
comment: cars have to turn at a traffic light and are slow ... not to much place to stop but possible

name: Anonymous
comment:
Easy to find a lift to the north like cologne or bonn, much harder to find someone going to the east or frankfurt.
its an average at all.

name: Anonymous
comment: Great place to hitch on the A20, accessable by tram 2 or 5 stop 'Südblick'.  Bring a sign for A20 East or West.

name: Anonymous
comment: There's a part of the road when crosing the border with a 10km/h speed limit. I got a ride in a couple of minutes, barely put my Munich sign up and a car sopped. There is also a place for them to park so a perfect place for hitchhiking (it's before the small petrol station - there's more traffic, as only some of the cars go to the station).

name: Anonymous
comment: There is a Shell Station on this road B75, very good to reach A7 South. You just get out of the subway at Berliner Tor and walk down the street.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very good roundabout to go either towards Kassel or Göttingen. Best way to reach the A7 from Witzenhausen.

name: Anonymous
comment: Parking space with a toilet. If you are coming from Frankfurt (Oder) or Poland and want to go West, but your driver goes to Berlin via the Schönefelderkreuz you should get off here. It is not so busy but sooner or later you will find somebody going further West.

name: Anonymous
comment: the service station Homburg is a quite good alternative for Goldene Bremm Süd in Saarbrücken, because there are more cars who take you till frankfurt or nürnberg (even Prag) but at least till Kaiserslautern and Mannheim. the waiting time really varies regularly.

name: Anonymous
comment: waited for more than anhour, nobody going towards nürnberg (A3)

name: Anonymous
comment: nobody going to nürnberg, could be good for munich

name: Anonymous
comment: bad place to stop, and its not allowed to stop as well

name: Anonymous
comment: To the North (Gifhorn) or on the A2. Stand at empty parking lots

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot for every direction. nice spot for cars to stop and they are still going slow there

name: Anonymous
comment: Easy to get a ride to the East

name: Anonymous
comment: not the best spot to stop, but worked pretty good

name: Anonymous
comment: spot to get to the autobahn, or on the autobahn towards heilbronn

name: Anonymous
comment: don't end up here. my truck driver needed a break and dropped me of there. If u end up here, ask everybody if they can take you towards Bruchsal, the next gas-station. Not much traffic

name: Anonymous
comment: Hitchhikingspot in direction Alsfeld/highway. You can take a train from Marburg to Kirchhain to get here.

name: Anonymous
comment: After walking through all the Michendorf from the Raststatte and showing a sign POTSDAM a driver took us to Potsdam while we were passing the zebra crossing here.

name: Anonymous
comment: Great place to get to Berlin. First driver we asked took us to the outskirts of the capital.

name: Anonymous
comment: The cars slow down on the traffic lights, but do not have time to stop. And mosst of the cars going north do not go on the A111, but after 500m they turn right to Hermsdorfer Damm.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Salzgitter

name: Anonymous
comment: Most cars going to HAnnover or Hildesheim. If you want to go south, you can also take a car to hannover and get out at Hildesheimer Börde on the A7 where it is possible tzo change the side of the motorway.

name: Anonymous
comment:
A relatively good place, if you try to get to Rendsburg.
If you want to get to A7 better try the spot right over the cross, at the traffic lights in front of IKEA.

name: Anonymous
comment: Towards Gardelegen, Haldesleben, Magdeburg

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus stop after traffic light at the crossing of streets Heilige-Grab and Nieskyer, perfect for direction of Dresden and highway A4 in general

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus stop called "Fiedler str." (I am not sure which bus is running to here, but it's also walkable from town center), very good for getting on the highway A4 but also for going north along B96

name: Anonymous
comment: Cars will be going somewhat slow from the traffic light.

name: Anonymous
comment: Big Gas Station on the autobahn A1 leading to Bremen from around Dusseldorf. Enough place to stop a car just before the entrance to the autobahn. Can reach by walking from RoxelerStr where bus No1 passes (stop: Ackerman) or from Dingbangerweg bus No 10 (very rare one).

name: Anonymous
comment: Getting to Muenster just before the Bus stop, leaving space for the car to stop at the bus place.

name: Anonymous
comment: Mostly local traffic going to the city only

name: Anonymous
comment: Should be a good place for all directions to N/NE. Not much space to stop but loads of traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment: Not much cars stopping around but generally a good spot.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot if you want to get from Deggendorf direction Phillipsreuth.

name: Anonymous
comment: This is the best place to get to Grafenau. Nevertheless, it's mostly German cars going to Grafenau or Freyung. Once the new road around the village will be opened, there will be no good spot to go to Grafenau from the motorway exit.

name: Anonymous
comment: Probably the best place of Grafenau, direction Freyung. There is almost nobody going to the Czech Republic though.

name: Anonymous
comment: Small parking lot near the crossroads, direction CZ. Cars are going very fast and it can be very hard for them to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: Not a good place to stop but otherwise you should get a lift easily.

name: Anonymous
comment: A good place on the way to Munich/Vienna.

name: Anonymous
comment: Nice place at the entrance to the motorway.

name: Anonymous
comment: Not a good place to pull over, but a lot of people go to Southeast.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very bad place, not much traffic and mostly local.

name: Anonymous
comment: Not much space to pull over, but sometimes you can get a long-distance lift.

name: Anonymous
comment: Almost nobody stops here.

name: Anonymous
comment: its an ok spot, there is a truck stop close to this onroad, more then enough place to stop, and if it rains you can stand underneath the bridge

name: Anonymous
comment: not that bad to go towards Chemnitz, A4, stay on the lights

name: Anonymous
comment: seemed quite useless to ask people at the petrol station

name: Anonymous
comment: bad place, we wanted to go towards Chemnitz, Nurnberg but we just wasted time and had to find another place- a petrol station to the south

name: Anonymous
comment: Good hitchhiking spot, only had to wait for ten minutes. Stood at the end with a sign, good to go further East (I had a sign saying 'Kassel')

name: Anonymous
comment: There are some construction works going on at the moment, I have waited for 45 mins and then I think I was extremely lucky and a guy got me to Michendorf.

name: Anonymous
comment: If you are lucky, one of the truck drivers will get you to Michendorf (where the chances are much higher) and maybe even further. You have to just go from car to car and ask for your possibilities.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good place to go to Kassel. Or the oposite direction.

name: Anonymous
comment: bus stop, good visibility

name: Anonymous
comment:
parking spot with toilet "goldene aue": going west this place seemed to be totally deserted. very few cars passed. to go away from here we had to convince a local driver that we are lost if he wouldn't give us a ride. he took us to the next parkplatz which was similar. 200 m west is a bridge over the autobahn and a hiking trail to the small village thürungen, the village berga, train station "berga-kelbra" and lake kelbra. from the train station you can go to kassel in 2 hours, halle in 50 min, nordhausen in 15 min. (the last direct connection to kassel starts at 18:08 pm and costs 26,40€).
but the landscape is absolutely beautiful! surrounded with hills you see the kyffhaeuser mountain. a sign informs about the interesting historic sights near here. i can imagine starting a hiking tour here. there's the beautiful lake kelbra very near on the other side of the autobahn.

name: Anonymous
comment:
parking spot with toilet "goldene aue": going west this place seemed to be totally deserted. very few cars passed. to go away from here we had to convince a local driver that we are lost if he wouldn't give us a ride. he took us to the next parkplatz which was similar. 200 m west is a bridge over the autobahn and a hiking trail to the village berga, train station "berga-kelbra" (3 km), lake kelbra (3,5 km) and the kyhaeuser forest (5 km). from the train station you can go to kassel in 2 hours, halle in 50 min, nordhausen in 15 min. (the last direct connection to kassel starts at 6:08 pm and costs 26,40€, the absolut last train is at 8:08 pm).
but the landscape is absolutely beautiful! surrounded with hills you see the kyffhaeuser mountain. a sign informs about the interesting historic sights near here. i can imagine starting a hiking tour here. there's the beautiful lake kelbra very near on the other side of the autobahn.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Görlitz or Poland. Quite small parking, but you can get there by local bus (bus stop Bretnig, ticket: VVO zone Radeberg) and some nice walking. Once there, ask anybody to bring you to the next big gas station ().

name: Anonymous
comment: In the bus stop I get a ride to Bremen in 20 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Guter Spot Richtung Norden oder ins Ruhrgebiet. Hinter der Tankstelle kann man sich super auf den Spurteiler stellen - da fahren die Leute langsam und man kann garnicht übersehen werden, Platz zum anhalten gibts reichlich. Da viele Fahrer bei Olpe Richtung Köln abbiegen ist jedoch ein Schild angebracht.

name: Anonymous
comment: This is a very big truck resting place, where I stayed for a whole night, than I started to hitchhike early in the morning. I got a ride in 10 minutes (for approximately 560 km). The best place to hitchhike through the A3.

name: Anonymous
comment: I got a ride to Amsterdam in 3 minutes. I just put my sign out and a woman with a sportcar stopped next to me. Awesome hitchhiking spot! :]

name: Anonymous
comment: It was a little bit unlucky HH spot for me, because it took me 3 hours to get a ride to München! :) Finally, a blonde woman with a 4 years old kid stopped to me and took me to the city center. But after all, I guess it was just a rare thing.

name: Anonymous
comment: When I got out of the car, suddenly a young soldier stopped right to me, but was going to Innsbruck, so I did not go with him. After that, one crazy guy took me near München in 5 minutes. So, quiet a good spot! Direction: Siegsdorf, Rosenheim, München.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good Spot for going downhill to Nürtingen / Beuren / Owen. Cars can easily stop.

name: Anonymous
comment:
For going to Nürtingen this sport works perfect.
Coming from Nürtingen is not that good cause cars going to Owen or Beuren cannot stop easily.

name: Anonymous
comment: Leaving Nürtingen for Owen / Beuren / Erkenbrechtsweiler, this is the perfect spot.

name: Anonymous
comment: For going to Kirchheim Teck this is a good spot because there is a part where the "Gehsteig" is low.

name: Anonymous
comment: The Busstation is a good place to hitch to Nürtingen.

name: Anonymous
comment: For going to Nürtingen / Reudern this is a good place because the cars can stop easily.

name: Anonymous
comment: For going onto B27 this is quite good. I usually use this to go to Nürtingen, but most cars go direction Stuttgart. With a sign it works.

name: Anonymous
comment: Here a lot of cars leave Tübingen für the B27. They go in all kind of directions from there.

name: Anonymous
comment: don't know if I was just lucky, but I got a ride after 2 minutes directly to Berlin from here. I think it's the best spot for everybody who wants to hitchhike large distances from Switzerland to the north of Germany

name: Anonymous
comment: tried for one day to get a ride to Czech, asked about 200 people, looked a long time for czech cars, it's NOT possible! and I think to berlin it's also not a good place. you may think it's a good spot because there are thousand cars but don't hitchhike here!!

name: Anonymous
comment: Stood here once, going north, in summer, vacation/traveltime, very full with cars from the highway at the petrol station. Probably also cars going south.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good spot for hitching to the A3 direction Frankfurt. Space for cars to stop, and fast road with probably most cars going to the motorway. Only one experience so far, though.

Guter Platz, um auf die A3 Richtung Frankfurt zu trampen. Platz für Autos, anzuhalten und ich glaube, alle Autos fahren auf die Autobahn, oder zumindest bis dahin. Aber erst einmal ausprobiert.

name: Anonymous
comment: Wir warteten etwa 20 min an der Esso-Tankstelle bis uns der hierzu gehörende Abschleppdienst mit zur Raststätte bei der Autobahnauffahrt gebracht hat.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Bus stop „Eichenplatz“; the #4 bus towards Boefingen stops here.
Just stand there with a sign saying „HDH“ to get a lift onto the A7 northbound. Tell the driver to drop you at Lonetal services if they don't go any further than Heidenheim. Never had to wait for more than ten minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Petrol station northwards (Buddikate West). Should work well for rides towards Luebeck (A1), worked okay for hitching a ride onto the A20 east to Wismar, Rostock and Greifswald

name: Anonymous
comment: very easy to find from tramstop; auestadio. a bus stop just before the lights. You need a sign. not very good place but it worked for me,

name: Anonymous
comment: The petroll station with rest area. there is not very high traffic, but I got there a lift for 500 km.

name: Anonymous
comment: Rest area Theißtal. Reachable in a 20 minutes walk from Niedernhausen. Good for going north.

name: Anonymous
comment: Spend maybe 2 hours to find a car to Prag. Result: zero :(

name: Anonymous
comment: NO WAY OUT TO PRAG! Spend maybe 5 hours and no result! road of dead! Only way - go back to Dresden and find somebody on a parking. Don't stay here

name: Anonymous
comment: Direction of Roermond, wait at the traffic light, enough place for cars to stop!

name: Anonymous
comment: Esso Gas station, high frequented, most cars go to autobahn to south or north

name: Anonymous
comment: The on-ramp sign's scratchmarks tell a history of hitchhikers being stranded here on the way to Berlin. Maybe there is a time during the day where you can _easily_ get a lift here. We haven't found it so far (during the evening). Correct this entry if you know otherwise.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Petrol station “Stolpe Süd”. This is a pretty decent-sized rest area (with showers and stuff) half way between Hamburg and Berlin.

Lots of traffic running into Berlin (and Polish cars going beyond). Even well into the late evening/beginning night, you should be able to get a lift to Berlin from here.

name: Anonymous
comment: Spot directly at the customs place (Zollstation). Hold out a sign or talk directly to the people when they get out and chat with the police. Cars are driving slow and nobody complained.

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus stop and a low side wall, on which you can stand to be more visible for passing drivers. A lot of inner city traffic, but also many people are heading west, like Magdeburg or Hannover

name: Anonymous
comment: Not so easy to get here, but after 1,5 hour waiting time a nice woman with a Jaguar stopped to me and took a ride up to the motorway. Cars are coming from 2 ways, but lot of people just go few kilometers.

name: Anonymous
comment: I waited 30 minutes to get a ride to Aachen. The traffic is high.

name: Anonymous
comment: It was getting darker and darker, when I got a ride to Bruxelles. Nice place with small airplanes in the air sometimes :)

name: Anonymous
comment: I waited here 4 hours and then a I had to ask a French lorry driver to take me out of this senseless place (well, it was just a 30 km long ride). Nearly impossible to catch a ride to the North. Everybody went to Stuttgart or to the South or West. For me it was one of the WORST hitchhiking places ever. Have a big luck everybody!

name: Anonymous
comment: I waited here approximately 20 minutes and finally got a ride direction Koblenz (I was on my trip to Bruxelles, then London). I hitchhiked at the curve where I signed it.

name: Anonymous
comment: Small parking area with toilets. Good spot for heading north to Hamburg. Just ask the driver. I found a lift directly to Wismar.

name: Anonymous
comment: Gas station with service area. Direction south.

name: Anonymous
comment: Lot of space to stop. Mainly cars to Schleswig. If you want to go further, try to get to the motorway-onramp of A7 in Schleswig-Schuby to the west.

name: Anonymous
comment: Traffic light and a lot of space to stop. Busstop nearby. Rushhour works good, many people work in Schleswig.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Traffic lights. Not easy to stop. Most traffic goes up the coast (direction Kappeln).
100m down the street is a gas station which has very cheap prices, so there is a lot of traffic. We had better luck on this spot at the street.

name: Anonymous
comment:
I hitch hiked there(Terminal 2) wanting to go direction A5, North. I had a sign with it. Although there is a lot of traffic, the people either are anxious for a reason or not have so much time to think about getting you. 
Nevertheless, there was a man who drove me until the first Rasthof in A5 direction South(Darmstadt).

name: Anonymous
comment: I don't know if I point it well, but I mean the station which is after the exit number 3 on the A5 highway direction east. There is a great point to hitch hike.Too much traffic there. I took a ride almost to Hannover

name: Anonymous
comment:
Here is the Klinikum bus station. I started hitch-hiking from this spot to go to Dresden on 9th of August 2012.

There is enough place to stop and traffic is not so high but local people are not willing to give us a lift. We were two boys.

name: Anonymous
comment: you are almost middle of nowhere here. If you have good luck you will take a lift  soon. i hitched a car on 9th of August 2012

name: Anonymous
comment: I used this place few times, when i went to Netherlands and i had no idea how to get there. Take s-bahn 11, take right excit, then go left, there is traffic circle, under sign "alles richtung". You can stay on the striped area before split roads (one goes to hotel) or in the lawn in the last turn from traffic circle, there is no place to stop, but cars do it, because road is wide enough. I was waiting there first time about 20 minutes, the last one something about 1 hour.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to get on the A9 direction Leipzig/Berlin. Here are more cars than on the gas station. Many of them have to stop at the traffic lights anyway, some use the beginning of the slip road.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good Spot to go to the North. There are many cars going to the Motorway and they are slow.

name: Anonymous
comment: Tu jest fajne miejsce na łapanie stopa w kierunku północnym.

name: Anonymous
comment: Search for "Altglienicke" on hitchwiki to get here. Possible to stand here or a few meters down the road at the traffic light.

name: Anonymous
comment:
I started here to get onto the A8.
There is a bus stop and a traffic light here (so people can stop w/out disturbing the traffic). But there is quite little traffic, so I waited 1,5 hours.

name: Anonymous
comment:
This spot is placed WRONG. The whole pier area is prohibitited for pedestrians! For hitchhiking see the two points below: the Ferry Ticket Center or (even before the Ticket Center) the roundabout.
Attention: currently (Sept'12) both Open Street Map an Google Maps  are not up to date in this area. Only satellite view of bing maps shows the right buildings and streets!

name: Anonymous
comment: People who bought a ferry ticket in advance drive by here (a few meters behind the exit of the roundabout).

name: Anonymous
comment: Good place at tha Bundesstraße to Ingolstadt and on the local McDonalds. So you could stand next to the street, but you should use a sign, or talk directly to people at the parking plac of the fast food restaurant.

name: Anonymous
comment: Base to go througth the north or the south to regensburg. There is a McDonalds Restaurant and a Gas station and you could talk to many drivers.

name: Anonymous
comment: Base to go througth the north or the south to regensburg. There is a McDonalds Restaurant and a Gas station and you could talk to many drivers.

name: Anonymous
comment: a great place for hitchiking masochists. if you get to this hellish gas stations somehow, just kill yourself. or start walking in any direction away. (but if you still get stuck there like us, you can get a but from gross mackenstedt)

name: Anonymous
comment: This is a spot to get from the A70 to the A7 if you are driving with someone who doesn't want to drive on the A7.

name: Anonymous
comment: Из Берлина до Бейлитц идет электричка с пересадкой. Недалеко трасса (30 минут пешком) и можно быстро поймать машину в сторону  Мюнхена.

name: Anonymous
comment: It's perfect spot to go to Dresden. Easy. If you want to go to Prague, it's also possible.

name: Anonymous
comment: Traffic light. Great for getting rides into the city, even at in the dark, because you can just ask people waiting at the red light.

name: Anonymous
comment: This spot is ok for leaving Dresden. If you want to go to Prague, don't be late. Lot's of cars are taking long distances mornings. There is not any Petrol Station. There is just toilets. It's also quite ok for camping if you arrive there so late. good luck ;)

name: Anonymous
comment: We tried to hitchhike on B300 towards Augsburg in a place that looked very good to stop cars, but in 5 minutes came a police cars just to tell us to go away. they put us in a worse place, of course, were we had to wait for more then an hour.

name: Anonymous
comment: Towards Augsburg and Suttgart and also Munich. Very few cars go here and many of them refuse with a nice smile.

name: Anonymous
comment: Big parking place from both sides of the road and also a traffic light. Many people to ask around if you are heading towards Stuttgard or Munich. Most of them go to Munich though.

name: Anonymous
comment: Small highway stop, not many cars stopping - but good to catch a ride down South in direction Passau. Starting at try this spot in the darkness is senseless. Its reachable the spot from the IKEA Bus stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: To St Vith, Liege. Not so much traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Wittlich. Fast traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Belgium, St Vith, Liege

name: Anonymous
comment:
I waited 10 min to get a ride
to the next Gas Station 20km down the A8. from there it was easy
Traffic here comes car by car, so its easy for them to stop!
Take the Subway to Airport and walk there.

name: Anonymous
comment: as the Rasthof Kassel in august  2012 was still closed i came to the Autohof (shell) petrol station and the first car driver asked took me to Karlsruhe. Very good

name: Anonymous
comment: Liege / Verviers

name: Anonymous
comment: To Luckau / A13.

name: Anonymous
comment: Most cars towards Frankfurt, some towards Bad Hersfeld/Erfurt.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Szczecin / do szczecina.

name: Anonymous
comment: Rasthof Oberschelden West.

name: Anonymous
comment: Based on one experience not a good spot to get to Rasthof Frechen.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to hitch a lift to Mont Royal Summer Camp!

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to hitch a lift to Mont Royal Summer Camp!

name: Anonymous
comment: Directly at the Driveway. The Cars have to stop on the road. Traffic is quite high.

name: Anonymous
comment: gas station

name: Anonymous
comment: A parking with an opportunity to hitchhike towards Innsbruck.

name: Anonymous
comment: Was waiting here on monday for over 1 1/2 hour from 1pm to hald past 2pm for a jump to Salzburg. The station is beautiful, but the place not so effective. I jumped around between the Shell station and the Burger King Park Place and the Dot I did.

name: Anonymous
comment: Got a jumb to the Busstation near Dolzig after 30min. Waited there cause really without money even for bus and walking on the B181 is to dangerous.

name: Anonymous
comment: I put my thumb up here to go on A3 heading south; I got a ride in about half an hour.

name: Anonymous
comment: A small parking for park+ride system, where people are leaving their cars and sharing a ride with others going the same direction. Even though it was already too late for that, we found a ride after 5 minutes to take us to the nearest gas station on the highway in the direction of the Netherlands.

name: Anonymous
comment: second guy i asked took me close to rostock... but there is not a lot going on at night lucky me then!^^

name: Anonymous
comment:
it is kinda hard to get somethiong northbound! but south bound no 
problem!
i tried northbound twice once it took me and a friend 1,5 hours and the second time  the second guy i asked took me till leipzig!

name: Anonymous
comment: Parking place with a small imbis/restaurant and toilets but no gas-station. Very good to start a trip, if you have someone who brings you to the field road behind that place.

name: Anonymous
comment: Rasthof Cloerbruch Nord A52 toward Viersen and Roermond (NL), petrol station plus restaurant, average sized carpark.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Bus stop on Rheinkniebrücke toward Viersen and Roermond/Venlo (NL) and A52 highway.

Lots of place to stop, didn't see any buses while we were waiting for a ride. Drivers can see you quite well.

We ended up in Roermond on a spot where we couldn't get a ride. Therefore, going north toward Arnhem might be a better bet.

name: Anonymous
comment: I think this was the exact spot - right after the second long term car park, about ten minutes walk from the terminal. I was hhiking with a sign for Switzerland. Very few cars, but some stopped within 5 minutes and wanted to take me to Memmingen or Munich. In 20 minutes I got a ride to Zurich (the driver wanted €20 though). Another man was hhiking in front of me, trying to get to Ulm and had stayed there for more than an hour. Maybe I was just lucky. The sign with the Swiss flag definitely helped.

name: Anonymous
comment: Dresdner Tor - A4 direction Görlitz.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Service station Plötzetal Ost on the A14 direction Magdeburg.

Not that many cars fill up their petrol here, maybe because it's still quite close from PL/CZ?

name: Anonymous
comment: Gas station towards Swiss border

name: Anonymous
comment: good Place for find someone to go into City

name: Anonymous
comment: ein guter Platz für Leute die nach Hamburg oder Rostock wollen

name: Anonymous
comment: good to reach with the tram (Saarbrückner Str) and go to Berlin or Dresden

name: Anonymous
comment: Direction Trier / Luxembourg / Saarbrucken.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Trier / Luxembourg / Saarbrucken.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Saarbrucken / Merzig

name: Anonymous
comment: In the direction of Tübingen. Good visibility as cars are passing slow and there's a stretch where no cars are allowed to park (bus stop, etc). Plenty of room for cars to pull over quickly.

name: Anonymous
comment: Rest place full of cars going north towards Munich and south towards Innsbruck. Stand at the exit of the rest stop, here the cars driving on the road also see you.

name: Anonymous
comment: cars are very fast and the road is wide, but the shoulder permits plenty of space.

name: Anonymous
comment: Junction towards Rheine-Mesum. Low traffic, but driving slow due to traffic lights.

name: Anonymous
comment: Junction B481/L578. Towards Elte quite some traffic, mostly going further to Rheine-Gellendorf.

name: Anonymous
comment:
On-ramp Hörstel towards Amsterdam.

Normal traffic, mostly towards Rheine.

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus stop in front of Liebherr. Direction Muensingen

name: Anonymous
comment: This is a good spot to hitchhike towards south on A3. I got a ride from here in about 20 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Aral gas station at Autohof Ilmtal. only westbound cars.

name: Anonymous
comment:
you can reach this spot with tram 17 to Amalienburgerstraße, like 20 min from main station.
Good stopping opportunity, but not best light. But there is also a direct bus going further which stops directly before the A8 (Halt Blutenburg)

name: Anonymous
comment:
Direction: South
Just a parking, not best frequented. I don't remember how long I waited, but it was long (>1.5h), but then I got a fast lift to the bavarian border (Frankental)

name: Anonymous
comment: Direkt hinter der Ampel Fahrbahn mit Standstreifen :-)

name: Anonymous
comment:
Schlechte anhalte Punkte :-( 
Besser mit dem Bus zum Rastplatz in Urloffen.

name: Anonymous
comment: Von der Haltestelle "Connewitz Kreuz" entweder Straßenbahnlinie 9 nehmen oder zu Fuß zweihundert Meter südlich Richtung B2 laufen. Die südlichen Fahrer haben eine eigene Spur, die unter der Brücke durchführt. VOR der Brücke kann man gut stehen, die Straße ist recht breit. Unter der Brücke wird der Erfolg sich in Grenzen halten. Die B2 führt zur A38, welche zur A9 führt. Schreibt auf ein Schild A9 und geht sicher, dass ihr mindestens bis Osterfeld auf die A9 kommt.

name: Anonymous
comment: good to hitchhike towards south on A9. Many cars stop at IKEA to do a short break while there journey. Of course - many people with full cars or families.on the other handside - thousands of cars!!! I had luck - 10minutes walking over the parking place. Look at the label for the area at the cars.

name: Anonymous
comment:
shell gas station.
take the train to Senne and then walk or take a bus to bus-stop 'airport' (Flugplatz)

name: Anonymous
comment: theres some space next to a spring called schäferquelle - perfect spot if wanna get a lift to a2

name: Anonymous
comment: there are some parking spots where you can easily stand and wait for a lift, good for getting south

name: Anonymous
comment: never ever get off at neermoor, no space, high speed traffic - the only change that you can have is a gas station close by which is used by mainly locals

name: Anonymous
comment: try to avoid this ramp, theres hardly no chance to get a lift (if you get off there you should rather walk to aschendorf and take the train...)

name: Anonymous
comment: very good resting place for hitchhiking south to ruhrgebiet - take a sign or talk to people

name: Anonymous
comment: just after the cross road theres some space at the road side, good for getting onto the a42, travelling east or west

name: Anonymous
comment: Hier kannst du die Leute persönlich fragen. Ansonsten ist die gesamte Str. sehr gut geeignet! Zu erreichen mit der Line 2 nach und bis Sieker oder der 3 nach und bis Stieghorst.

name: Anonymous
comment: Schwierig. Wenn du in den Süden fahren möchtest Stell dich nahe der Auffahrt der A2 an der Detmolder Str.(Stieghorst/Sieker)  hin und fahr erst nach Hannover und dann auf die A7 Richtung Kassel etc.

name: Anonymous
comment: Um auf die A7 zu kommen besser noch mal zurück fahren und von Raststätte Steigerwald versuchen.

name: Anonymous
comment:
We hitchhiked to Poland from here and asked drivers directly on the petrol station. 

Its easy to get a lift.
Waiting Time: 5 min

name: Anonymous
comment: Great spot of you are arriving on the A3 and are looking at going South towards Munich. If you go further to the main interchange there is no where to pull over for your driver. Here is it wasy to turn around and get back on the highway. I was staying in the town just 15km north (Lauf) for the night, you can easly hitch the 15km from here and get to Lauf Bahnhof (Links der Pegnitz) and then walk the 1km to the A9 onramp, there is a station there where you can get a lift on the A9

name: Anonymous
comment: Who the hell is hitching in the Forest? LOL :P

name: Anonymous
comment: Reached this gas station at 2 a clok in the night, so we slept a round in the petrolstation, really nice service there. in the morning 6am we ask fucking everybody for a lift to the north. but all truckers went into munich and other cars also for work. at 8am this changed and somebody tooks us to nürnberg but in the morning in the week this spot was shit! probably its diffrent on the day.

name: Anonymous
comment:
A spot to hitch towards Heilbronn, Stuttgart.
I hitched just next to the autobahn sign. There is not much space to pull over, but I got a ride within 5 minutes, who actually drove to Heidelberg, but decided to help me and brought me directly to Stuttgart.

name: Anonymous
comment: Perfect spot for going on A1 in both directions. waited 5 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good place: it has a gas station, food/restaurant, a big parking lot and is most importantly decently busy.
Great place towards Dresden obviously, but also direction Prague/Praha (CZ) and Wroclaw (PL) !!

name: Anonymous
comment: Aral gas station/Autohof. More cars towards Hannover?!

name: Anonymous
comment: Shell petrol station with a lot of traffic to the east, at least to Nürnberg

name: Anonymous
comment: Average spot to hitch southbound. Either ask drivers or stand next to the traffic light a little further

name: Anonymous
comment:
To the East (Cologne) onto the A4 or North-East onto the A44. Short local rides can usually drop you on the service station Aachener Land on the A4. 

Two lanes merging into one, but no real margin. Still, enough space to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: At a road with a lot of traffic. Cars can see you quite late, but it is still okay. The good thing is that it is directly at a bus stop and a traffic light. So the cars can pick you up easily.

name: Anonymous
comment: All the cars coming from Lübeck in direction to Hamburg will come by here and there is a good place for the cars to stop...

name: Anonymous
comment: Drivers coming from Stockelsdorf can be stopped here quite good as there is an entry to the gas station were people can park. People drive in both directions: Hamburg and Travemünde. However, I'd rather suggest to go directly to the exits on the other side of the street...

name: Anonymous
comment: Very good spot. All the cars coming from the gas station and from Münchberg come by here. There is some space to stop for the cars in the entrance to the motorway...

name: Anonymous
comment: Good station to go north! Either stand at the entry to the motorway and show your thumb or ask the people at the gas station...

name: Anonymous
comment: Try not to get dropped here. You will be picked up eventually but there is not much traffic...I was picked up after 30 minutes...

name: Anonymous
comment: I`ve wait one half hour for go straight to berlin.a good place to wait with a lot of cars.

name: Anonymous
comment: This is a very good spot to head west as there is plenty of space for cars and trucks to stop and they go pretty slowly after the roundabout. I was here for about 40 minutes and 3 drivers stopped, one about every 15 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to head north; space for the cars to stop and they drive slowly enough to allow a good body language communication between the hitchhiker and the driver. I hitchhiked from here more than once heading Naumburg.

name: Anonymous
comment: Avoid it!

name: Anonymous
comment: This place is no good for hitchhiking; there is a crosslight here but no space at all for the cars to stop because of the guardrail. I got a ride from here on a winter day with blowing snow in about 20 minutes, but I would not choose this spot again; instead, to go south the best is to walk on the other side of the bridge for about 1 km until the guardrail ends and there there will be plenty of space for the cars to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: This place is good to head south on B2. I got a ride from here to Gera.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very good spot heading west or south.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very good spot to head north. After the bridge, there is plenty of space for the cars to stop and the speed is quite low because there is also a crosslight.

name: Anonymous
comment: 10 min gewartet, Sonntag 17.03. Direkt nach Dresden.

name: Anonymous
comment: Parking lot for commuters, easy to get a hike to Trier/Luxemburg, but only in the early morning.

name: Anonymous
comment: Altenburger Raststätte

name: Anonymous
comment: a lot of cars going north or south, but  very rare to park. maybe better to take "Landau Süd" and stand there. There is a gas station in "Weißenburger Str." that could be a better spot.

name: Anonymous
comment: hard to park for cars, but a lot of them going north and south from here.

name: Anonymous
comment: really bad place! only local traffic, except some shopping-tourism going back to france. nearly hopeless to go in directing of e.g. karlsruhe (march 12)

name: Anonymous
comment:
only for direction leipzig/berlin:
really bad place! mostly local traffic just to lobeda - locals going to leipzig seem to use b7 avoiding the hermsdorfer kreuz - try there!

name: Anonymous
comment: very good spot to go to the a9 and then in direction of leipzig! busstation to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment:
horrible place! the autohof is really small!
when i was there i found nobody within 3 hours going in direction to berlin or at least staying loing enough on the a9 till the next gas station. nearly everbody going in direction to nürnberg.
if you are there speak to the people directly - it's the only chance!

name: Anonymous
comment: Asking people inside/outside the gas station if they are going to Berlin worked out great for me. Many use it as a pit stop before going on the Autobahn to Berlin. Be discrete and friendly so the Total staff won't give you problems.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to travel to Uelzen (especially if you missed the train, which leaves every hour at half past), if you're lucky, you can also get a ride to Hamburg

name: Anonymous
comment: quite good to get on the A29

name: Anonymous
comment:
Resting point.
En route north. Not extremely many cars or trucks, but enough. You can speak with the drivers. In my case all were friendly.
Most of them went to Dresden or further to Poland. But I found someone going to Berlin

name: Anonymous
comment: This is quite a big "Autohof" (including a McDonald's) with traffic in both directions. Although generally it's not recommendable to get off at an Autohof due to local and/or low traffic, this one seems ok to get to A30/East.

name: Anonymous
comment: I got here with the S1 from Frankfurt till Weiskirschen, and a long walk. I got a ride in less than 5' but it was local.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to hitchhike to the south. You should wait next to "Merkur" before the gas station so that the cars can stop safely at the gas station.

name: Anonymous
comment: Got dropped off here by a local who said it would be a good place to hitchhike from. Stood here for a while trying to get onto the E40 heading to Cologne, and it wasn't a great spot. Not much traffic, and though a few people offered us lifts, most of them were only going very small distances. Eventually got a lift quite a bit of the way to Cologne though, but it took patience.

name: Anonymous
comment: Man kann an der Aral-Tankstelle Leute ansprechen, morgens sehr viel Verkehr. Aber wenige fahren auf die Autobahn.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good Spot to get on the A6 in direction of Heilbronn. I guess it ist even good to go to München.

There are traffic lights which slow down the cars and a busstop behind the crossing.

name: Anonymous
comment: Me and my friend were hitchhiking from this spot to A2 towards Han and Cologne. We were taken to the north to a gasstation on the Autobahn. Took us 15min to catch a nice girl.

name: Anonymous
comment: This seems to be an obsolete marker as they have changed all the roads at the airport. Maybe an admin can delete it?

name: Anonymous
comment: Not exactly sure what was intended to be marked here as I haven't used this spot myself. Looks like it is one of the exits from the parking garage. Directions of travel from this point could be limited. Please update this description with your experience.

name: Anonymous
comment: got frustrated with the service station nearby & walked up. nice layby, chased away by the cops, caught a lift at the entrance where there is 0 space to stop...

name: Anonymous
comment: Bon point de stop pour aller en direction de la voie rapide qui va a Frankfurt! Attendre juste après le stade!

name: Anonymous
comment: Couldn't get a ride towards Berlin after 90 minutes of waiting.

name: Anonymous
comment: No space to pull over. There is a traffic light so it is still worth a go. About 3km back towards Leinefelde right in front of the supermarket is a traffic light, too. Plenty of space to pull over there.

name: Anonymous
comment: There is a traffic light were cars have to stop before they enter the highway.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot for going towards Jena and from there onto the A4. Cars are going slow and plenty of space to pull over. Not that much traffic.

name: Anonymous
comment: I know it under the name Harburger Berge, Good spot to get south.

name: Anonymous
comment: We hitchhiked from here west to the airport Frankfurt Hahn. It was 10pm and so dark, and no cars slowed down or even looked interested for a good 45 minutes, thankfully we got picked up by the actual airport bus and given a lift all the way there, however i think we just got lucky, wouldnt recommend this spot for getting to frankfurt hahn.

name: Anonymous
comment: good spot to go towards bremen and hamburg, i got a ride in 1 min to a gasstation on the highway from there i got to hamburg in 2 min.

name: Anonymous
comment: i got droped of at Autohof Altenwerder Bärbel Uliczka, crossed the train traks and walked under the bridges to this dangerous spot, but you can stand in between the two roads and ask people at the trafic light, just got a ride to the other side of the tunnel, and it is better to take the bus to the other side of the tunnel. A7 towards kiel/flensburg

name: Anonymous
comment: A gas station and car wash at a stoplight.

name: Anonymous
comment:
This is the travig cors in Dießen.
Do you like to find a car, fastly?
Than you have to stand clos to the travig lit. 
And if the lide gets red, you have to go to the cars with are stopt now. and ask for an lift. :D

name: Anonymous
comment: it took 7-8 mins to find a car to Bamberg. Cars have to wait for the lights and almost all cars are passing through Bamberg.

name: Anonymous
comment: It is an excellent spot. You can stand there easily next to the road and cars can stop at several small entrances to pick you up. So, you can always switch between several spots in a distance of 200m behind the gas station. I was picked up after 25 minuts and got a lift to Berlin Alexanderplatz. So, not too much, but enough cars going ahead to Berlin, the rest is just local traffic or sourrounds the capital via A10. If you are not successful, just ask the people refueling their cars at the gas station. But I think, that you mostly get your lift after at least 20 minuts, since the people in that area are not really used to seeing hitchhikers on that way.

name: Anonymous
comment: Saturday in May, got a hike in 5 min to Schwabisch Gmund, without asking - was crossing the road wondering where to go. Was a local bringing me there specially, didn't have to go there.

name: Anonymous
comment: Dropped of at the haubtstrasse, got in 2 minutes a car of locals to Lautern - where I had to go. Saturdayeve in may.

name: Anonymous
comment: Cars queue before the terminal for the ferry, you can ask people that are waiting around. Unfortunately I can't pinpoint the exact location but the area is pretty small, just explore it a little bit, start from the building where tickets are being sold (Scandlines) and figure out the route cars have to take to get on the ferry. In April 2013 it was still possible to use the ferry for free because payment is the same regardless of number of passengers in the car. Explain this to the drivers and you'll have no problem finding a ride. On the ferry ask people to get a ride further, you can find one to Copenhagen or even further.

name: Anonymous
comment: Petrol station am Hockenheimring Ost , direction Frankfurt/Koln good, Direction Koblenz average

name: Anonymous
comment: Small service Area. Got fuel station and some restaurants.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Gas & service station "Aurach".
To get there take bus 287 from Erlangen Hbf (train station) direction "Westfriedhof" until last but one stop ("Sankt Michael"). Walk 10 meters south (direction of bus) and then turn right (west). Walk straight for 10 minutes and your on the gas station.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Take the train to S Westend.

-Stand at the traffic lights. Lights are set so usually 5-6 cars stop at the red light, go through and then the next 5-6 cars have to stop. Plenty of time for them to decide if they want to give you a ride or not. Only thing here is that you have to pick one side so you miss a few cars.

OR

(Going South only)
-Stand behind the intersection right before the start of the highway. There's a spot where people can pull up. Thing here is that people are accelerating right where you stand (not so good).

I recommend the first option. Deffinitely recommend a sign here cos highway goes to many different directions shortly after.

Good spot imo, I found a ride all the way to Münster within 25mins. Good luck & enjoy :)

name: Anonymous
comment: Super Spot um auf die A4 zu kommen. Auf beiden Seiten sind hier Ampeln und direkt auf der rechten Seite ist eine kleine Einbuchtung, also auch ideal zum schnellen Einsteigen.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very bad spot. No space for the cars to stop. we gave up after 2 hrs and took train northwards to a service station

name: Anonymous
comment: Going north to Karlsruhe: There is a bus stop where people easily can stop for you. We were waiting for some 40 minutes before someone stopped - and took all 4 of us!

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus stop right after the big intersection. I was hitchhiking several times from here just to the next village Schallstadt which is maybe 7 kilometres to go. Never waited any longer than 15 minutes so definitely faster than going to the central station waiting for the next train.

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot if you want to go to the north (e.g.Berlin). Wait in front of the gas station and stop people taking the B172 to Dresden. Entering the highway is difficult as there is no space to park.

name: Anonymous
comment: Works fine when going to the north.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good spot when going to the north. Might also come handy if you're looking for a better entry to Berlin (e.g. your driver goes to the west but you prefer the east). Enough cars stop and asking people or waiting with a sign near the exit works.

This place has no gas station.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Gelmeroda
It's very easy to reach with the bus for just 1,90. There's a nice gas station and there are traffic lights, next to them a nice spot for the cars to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: really no good place to hitchhike!!

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot to go west (eg to the Netherlands).

name: Anonymous
comment:
Good place to get a ride in the direction of A8, Street lights and space for cars stop. Cars are not going to fast.
From the town center (bus station) get a bus or go by foot to the train staition, from there follow Sachsenkamer Straße in direction of Burger King, pass the roundabout and start HH.

I've waited about 15 minutes and got a lift till the gas station in A8 direction: Austria

name: Anonymous
comment: I was heading towards Ingolstadt from here which was quite a bit difficult. I first tried to stand at the road where is very little space for drivers to pull over but still it works. There is also a gas station at the opposite side so try both. To Augsburg would have been easier. It took me more than one hour in the bitter cold German March time until someone gave me a ride to Ingolstadt.

name: Anonymous
comment: If you ever go from Eichstatt to Pollenfeld in your life this is your spot! Make your way to get there and use the last bus stop before the narrow road goes uphill. Splendid experience :)

name: Anonymous
comment: There is a service station where cars can pull in or pull in for fueling up (ask people). Long straight raod so cars can see you from distance.

name: Anonymous
comment: Rest stop is called »Aichen«

name: Anonymous
comment: South side of the main train station. Ask around at the gas station, or also stand there on the grass with a sign to get people leaving from the station parking lot.

name: Anonymous
comment: Big service station with a restaurant. Number of cars depends on time of day of course, but it’s always easiest to wait at the gas station and ask.

name: Anonymous
comment: Vor der einfahrt zur Jet mit schild hinstellen oder an der Tanke fragen.

name: Anonymous
comment: Ok - to hitchhike, no margin though, but still possible to stop - good told twice by police to not hitchhike there in about 20 minutes...

name: Anonymous
comment: There is a gas station and a mc donalds and some other stuff in here (-> "Autohof), but when i got dropped here i waited quite long. The Gas Station at the highway a bit north is definetely a better place !

name: Anonymous
comment: Good for direction of Kassel, but if you are from Marburg i guess there is almost no public transport...

name: Anonymous
comment: I think its a good spot for going west. You can even camp a little bit outside of the service area (in the case it`s getting dark).

name: Anonymous
comment: Highway ramp close to the junction. easy to get seen, easy to stop for the cars. Its perfect to get a lift to the west and north (Mannheim, Frankfurt)

name: Anonymous
comment: On-ramp for the B402 near Schöninghsdorf. Completely deserted, don't get dropped off here!

name: Anonymous
comment: Big truckstop on the B213 direction A1/Bremen. There's a shoulder just behind the petrol station for cars turning off to the hotel, but perfect also to stop a car :) Should be possible to find somebody going onto the A1.

name: Anonymous
comment: on-ramp Ahrensburg, direction Lübeck. Just get a short ride to the petrol station 5km down the road.

name: Anonymous
comment: Lensahn, A1 direction Fehmarn. Nice on-ramp, might get you further towards Puttgarden.

name: Anonymous
comment: Burg a. F. direction Puttgarden. A bit of a hassle to get there, crossing the busy road, but fairly good spot.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Gast station. Next gas station from Frankfurt.
Get here by bus:
Take the 751 (Airport Terminal 1) to Gräfenhausen-Postplatz. Go to Hauptstarsse, turn right, then left on Trifftweg, go in the direction on Steinrodsee, 4th right, then left, and you will see the Gas Station.

Direction: A5 South Darmstadt, Heidelberg, Karlsruhe, Freiburg, Switzerland)

name: Anonymous
comment:
Super Ort für Fahrten nach Zwickau und Richtung A72.
Direkt nach der Tankstelle, gegenüber vom Lidl Supermarkt.
Durch abgesenkten Parkstreifen super Möglichkeit zum anhalten.
Hab nur 2 Minuten gewartet :)

name: Anonymous
comment: Last gas station before the highway. We were standing at the Werrepark bus stop. Lots of trucks but not really a place for them to stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: On-ramp near Bardowick. Useless to get around Lüneburg towards Uelzen. Spot is bad and you'd need multiple rides to get around. Better to walk.

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus stop Scharnhorststrasse, direction Uelzen. According to our driver this is the spot all the locals use, right next to the university :)

name: Anonymous
comment: Good spot on the 71 towards Salzwedel.

name: Anonymous
comment: Es ist ein

name: Anonymous
comment: Abgefahrene Landebucht für paradiesische Autoarten

name: Anonymous
comment: To Bitburg.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Definitely a great spot towards Koln over the B51! 

You can stand at the so called "late merge" or "zipper lane" / "Reißverschluss" on the right.

name: Anonymous
comment: Easy spot to get away southeast along the Mosel river. Hitchhiking is easy in this region, as often in rural areas.

name: Anonymous
comment: bus stop, we got a lift Sunday noon in about 20min

name: Anonymous
comment: Spend here 10 minuted to get a ride to Duisburg (25km north of Düsseldorf). After a night in Duisburg, i contunied to Amsterdam. You can wait at a side of a road, and show your sign at red light. At a side of a road there is quite a lot of grass, but generally it's ok.

name: Anonymous
comment: Before the traffic lights at the right side of the road. I used this spot to get to speedroad 59 to go north, to Amsterdam. It's logical to show your sign only when there is a red light, otherwise there is no place for car to stop. McDonald's with free toilette and wi-fi 150 meters away.

name: Anonymous
comment: Here is just enough space for car to stop, but i had no much luck here. You can try to use this spot to get to speedroad 59 to go north, to Amsterdam, for example. Unfortunately, car drivers don't have enough time to thihk about you, so i changed my position to one, before traffic lights and found a ride in 30 minutes. Probably it's also illegal for car drivers to stop here.

name: Anonymous
comment:
I asked around at the Aral-gas station (Took a bus from central Dresden to here, See wiki-page for Dresden).
Got a ride to central Prague after 30minutes at about 6 pm.

name: Anonymous
comment: Many cars towards Poland.

name: Anonymous
comment:
The simplest option to go directly to Leipzig.
Stand with a sign a few meters before the bus stop.
The spot is excellent (cars go relatively slowly and have lots of space to stop) but few are going directly to Leipzig.
Be patient, we (boy+girl) waited 40 mins.

name: Anonymous
comment:
To Chemnitz or south on highway A72.
Stand in the "closed from traffic" area marked here facing the drivers that are preparing to turn onto this road. They have enough space to stop.
Thumbing is enough (most cars go in one direction) but alternatively you can use a sign with a letter "C".

name: Anonymous
comment: On-ramp at Raunheim, A3. Seems like a good spot towards Koln, but it's only local traffic here and spot is 'half-legal'. Police sent us away after 30min.

name: Anonymous
comment: On-ramp 46 Niedernhausen, A3 towards Koln. Slow traffic and place for cars to stop at the side of the road.

name: Anonymous
comment: on-ramp 3 Emmerich, direction Arnhem (NL). Lots of dutch cars here.

name: Anonymous
comment: We used this spot to hitchhike south towards Hannover. There is a place to stop just behind the junction and you can make yourself visible to drivers coming from all directions. Furthermore this spot is in walking distance from the public bike station next to the Hammerbrook S-bahn stop.

name: Anonymous
comment: A decent spot to hitchhike south towards Hannover if you get dropped off at the nearby autohof. There's a luxury amount of space to stop at the side (though it's a highway ramp so it's already illegal). The forest opposite the autohof is also a good place to spend a night if you have a sleeping bag - we found loads of blueberries for breakfast around there :-)

name: Anonymous
comment: A good place to stand if you don't want to ask around - everybody leaving the area can see you and there's enough space to stop. In the summer we were struggling to get a ride east towards Leipzig because most cars leaving the parking were families going south for holidays.

name: Anonymous
comment: Little traffic but there's a decent space to stop at the ramp so the spot is usable if you get stuck around here.

name: Anonymous
comment: This looks like a good place to catch a lift towards Halle, Leipzig and maybe even further south. Tested only by friends of mine, waiting times 10-30 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Motorway station Streitau is small and has just a toilet house. Nevertheless there are always some cars and if you start hitchhiking  from Bayreuth and you just got a lift until Hof, Streitau is a good place to change cars. It never took me longer than 15 minutes.

name: Anonymous
comment: Autohof. It is really bad. A lot of local people but just a few going on the motorway A9.

name: Anonymous
comment: motorway station with a small toilet house. don't do that

name: Anonymous
comment: Parking place Moseltal. Not a lot of traffic, the cars are stopping mostly because of the view. Plus there are parking places for trucks as well. But in general there is not a lot of traffic, if possible, get out of the car on another spot.

name: Anonymous
comment: Bus station here, pretty decent for getting out of berlin. Got a ride in a few minutes to a gas station towards Stettin.

name: Anonymous
comment: nice spot i you wanna hitch to Kaltenkirchen (motorway) in order to get to Kiel or any other place in the north

name: Anonymous
comment: Little parking place. Not many cars stopped there.

name: Anonymous
comment: Karls Erlebnis Dorf is a huge strawberry farm and family vacation spot. There are bus stops on both lanes as well as a nearby petrol station. During the summer, Karl's is always crowded with people stopping by to get some strawberries on their way to the coast or, of course, on their ways home to Rostock, Hamburg, Berlin or even farther.

name: Anonymous
comment: To Zurich !! there is a very good space for cars to stop. I waited for 40 Min. and had a ride to Switzerland !! A police car asked me to stay behind the bar but that was OK !! The cars come fast so I would recommend holding A swiss flag with strong red rather than writing " Switzerland " on a paper !

name: Anonymous
comment: Direction Hof/A9. The right lane before the on-ramp is not perfect to stop, but ok.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Sehr viele Niederländer, gute Möglichkeit nach Venlo zu kommen. 
Nahezu unmöglich in Richtung Süden.

name: Anonymous
comment:
Going Northbound towards Nürnberg was impossible here because the on-ramp has no shoulder and the grass has poles that make it difficult for cars to pull into.  

Love,
The East Cackalacky Ascetic Marching Death Band

name: Anonymous
comment:
No shoulder for on-ramp!  Too dangerous.  There is a petrol station down the street and maybe you'll have better luck there...

Love,
The East Cackalacky Ascetic Marching Death Band

name: Anonymous
comment: It's not the worst spot to get a ride in all directions: South to Ilmenau (on the A71 always stand at the on-ramp, don't hope for gas stations or restplaces), East to Jena/Dresden and best West to Gotha/Eisenach/Hessen

name: Anonymous
comment: Better than nothing: There are not too many cars, but there is a restplace close to this on-ramp, so you will be able to get a ride in 10-15 min!

name: Anonymous
comment: A3 direction: north

name: Anonymous
comment: A1, beide Richtungen

name: Anonymous
comment: A bit difficult to get there. I tryed twice t get the direction to Regensburg-Passau... and it worked twice pretty well.

name: Anonymous
comment: Autobahnauffahrt, sehr gut um nach Köln zu kommen!

name: Anonymous
comment: Right after the traffic lights there's parking space where car can stop. Sign is necessary. Way to Stettin(Szczecin) and Hamburg. Easy to reach from tram M4 stop "Berliner Alee/Indira-Gandhi-Strasse" Not a bad place but perhaps the further spots could be better.

name: Anonymous
comment: Aral petrol station, easy going to reutlingen short waiting time by shield (busstation next to it) or asking people directly!

name: Anonymous
comment: a very good spot to go north on the A1, cars can stop easily on the little road on the right. we found it was a better place than just at the traffic lights.

name: Anonymous
comment: Total Station, there is not too much traffic and a lot of people just drive to places nearby but there is still the possibility to get a lift north- and southward bound on the A10. It seemed to me that there were more people going to the north than to the south.

name: Anonymous
comment: If you want to go West on the A2, you need to go to the other side of Hannover. I stood at this spot for an hour with a Dutch guy who had been here for three hours already. He gave up and took the train back to Amsterdam. I moved to the Gas station at Jäderkamp (I marked it on the map), and was also in Holland by midnight.

name: Anonymous
comment: Very good spot for getting out to Berlin, in Dresden direction. I stayed here just 10 minutes in a Sunday morning 6.00 a.m. You can get here using the Shoneweide S station

name: Anonymous
